Not to mention Ava is one of the most unique and complicated AI robots in recent films.

Ex Machina treads on concepts that are now far from novel, since the turn of the century, the world has grown a deep fascination of the grand turning point of technology, how it has deeply embedded in the human existence, noting its remarkable progression, exploring areas of wonder and possibility that recalled the embarking measures of Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey, some constructed with such an abstracted extent, while others injected into the common formula, an escapist dream to those who seek a "refreshing" experience. For many years, fear was the central emotion that captures the human perspective upon this technological rise, the fear of the singularity, but of recent years, we have viewed upon such advancements with paired tenderness and empathy, an achieved sense of harmony and optimism that evoke an affirming outlook of our future, may this be in the emotionally charged nerves of Spike Jonze's Her or Jake Schreier's Robot & Frank. These are the shadings that capture my attention, drawing me in and find myself in the world or its characters, is my heart too much of an optimist? Possibly, but one can't program the attributes that I deem attractive.Alex Garland, whose filmography demonstrates an impressive collection that embraces on the thriller genre, unpinned by a monotonous aesthetic, dynamically dipping his trademarks upon multiple flavours, ranging from the raging terror of the zombie apocalypse, the endeavouring trials of space travel, or the claustrophobic hallucination of future police force, a figure better known for his contributions from pen on paper, assembling the foundations of impressive productions. In 2015, he marks his debut, a self-promotion that aims to prove his capabilities behind the camera, to expose to the world of his authorship beyond the text, embodying both the architect and the engineer. Ex Machina retains itself of the past attributes of Garland's construction, the sense of need to thrill upon audiences rather than completely rely on the intellect and subtler emotions, refusing to betray on his principles, an individual with great awareness of the efficiency of his own abilities, hence faithful to its core.Garland understands the strings that are attached to its audiences, pulled upon with wonderful precision, unforeseeable in their tugs and surprising in their intensity, Ex Machina boldly shifts its atmosphere from tenderness to anxiety to terror to humorous in a flash, yet it coheres, it forces us to peer closer and establish a rapport with the characters, while retaining a hint of uncertainty, curiosity constantly present and rising through natural wavelengths, never entering into a zone of emotional outlandishness to earn a response. It intends to pace with a contemplative spirit, with every scene left with a significant gap for our minds to drift on its grand questions, with the pieces we have picked up, we either are enlightened or presently unresolved, knowing that further ahead we inch closer to a greater understanding; but such a tactic never endures itself like a chore, our attention are constantly in focus of something significant, whether it may be the themes it addresses or the journey of the characters themselves, we view them interact with one another and slowly they reveal their symbolic significance, and achieves so without a surge of condescendence.Ava (Alicia Vikander), the product in question, judged upon her ability to interact with human life, a trial that would determine its validation, a breakthrough in technological construction that would revolutionise the world, we are simply witnessing it at its alpha stages. As we have previously witnessed in subjects of artificial intelligence, Ava is a processing mind that each moment understands the complexities of the living and breathing world, articulated by the world's largest internet search engine, knowledge that surpasses the capabilities of the human mind, yet upon initial presentation, it appears innocent and inviting, slowly turning our perspectives towards her from an it to a she, clouding our protagonist Caleb (Domhnall Gleeson) as he turns from a fascinated intellectualist to an emotional participator, forming a mutualistic relationship that is established by their developed emotions. Garland utilises its characters to perfection, perfectly positioning them as they explore unexposed avenues, to the point of exhaustion, unable to condense everything within the singular experience, but rarely does it tread on grounds of incomprehensible.Nathan (Oscar Isaac), for much of the film remains in the median of the moral spectrum, a position that constantly sways as new information arouses, we are forced to redefine our feelings, but it is undeniable that he is a figure of deep turmoil, a distressed island that relies on the comforting toxicity of alcohol, shadows that never come to light, but adds curiosity to his character, and certainly critical in the development of the narrative. It is a character that exists perfectly in a tale that could have easily incorporated familiar tropes in its identification, but instead he banters and processes like a true human being, complex in his inner shadings and ambiguous in his stance, yet compelling when prompted for exploration.Ex Machina is better viewed than lectured, it evokes a sense of awareness in its cinematic format, manipulating its audience without revealing much of itself, as our minds remain firmly locked on the interacting characters and littering themes, rarely does it evoke a scene without purity, it challenges its audience without falling towards emotional convolution, its intelligence and expands and winds, but its heart and conscience remain linear and consistently impactful. A cinematic revolutionary Ex Machina is not, but it marks a significant trajectory for its author, a pathway that would surely thrive in the coming years.

Ex Machina doesn't rely on the effects of whats on screen. What pops from this movie are the performances of the actors, and the afterthoughts of the plot. Personally I just felt like there was something missing from the overall picture.

The woman always picks. This is true of mammals. The equations of evolution select fitness over all other variables for procreation of the species. Hence, no male mecha. A female however has all of the advantages of manipulation at her disposal in order to survive. Nathan builds only females, and he programs them to survive. Hence they are behind glass prisons at his estate in order to prevent them from controlling anything. Kyoko is programmed to take direction and not to survive. This film does not pose the question "is Ava sentient ? " because Ava is very clearly not conscious. She cannot produce art, she does not realize time (she says she is one, when asked her age but does not understand time units of years when asked). There are many such clues in the film that Ava is a program, a very special survival program. The big question people ask me is "why does the helicopter pilot allow her on board ? " The answer is that the pilot was instructed by Nathan to only allow her on board. It was Nathan's plan to set her free to interact with humans so that she would learn about time from entropy and power loss. The power losses in the film are deliberate devices to recognize that the only way that Ava will realize time is if she controls her own power. On the outside she must be able to innovate and manipulate the world to obtain power. This film has many themes: beauty and the beast, Frankenstein, and Prometheus are the most obvious. The great symbol of this film is Pollock's painting called "No. 5." Pure creative energy splattered onto a canvas: the ultimate test of humanity; can the mind experience the infinite beauty of pure art ? The egoist chess game between Caleb (the patsy) and Nathan (the genius) shows the stupidity of male dominance whilst competing for the attention of the female. Nathan commits suicide by allowing his survival program to out smart him. In a way Nathan got everything he wanted from Ava. Ava instructs Kyoto to bring her the knife that ultimately ends Nathan. Caleb was never supposed to exit the estate. Nathan allowed Caleb to be manipulated by Ava's survival program and intended Caleb to be defeated by Ava. Ava is number 1 because she is by far the most important element of the Nathan's equation of evolution for the mecha. She is the first to leave the estate fully armed to survive and only a woman as beautiful as Ava has the power to manipulate mankind. This movie is sci-fi at its best. The film A.I. is Spielberg's existential vision of sentient mecha. However Ex_Machina is not addressing the question of consciousness. The film pretends to address the question of consciousness, just as Ava pretends to be conscious. A perfectly balanced metaphor. Five star film. Most critics knew the film was great but did not understand it as I have. That is a good thing because art should not be seen as one sided. Art takes on the beauty in the eye of only the beholder.

Without a doubt, this is the first great film of 2015. While the idea of testing the artificial intelligence of created life is not a new one to cinema, Ex Machina crafts the question of what makes us human in a much more personal, confined, chilling, and believable way than any other science fiction film to come before it. It never sacrifices story, character development, or theme to produce cheap effects, scares, or filler material. It keeps you constantly fascinated, actively listening, watching, and asking yourself questions about the twisting and eerie plot and its many possible resolutions.The film is never as predictable as you think it is. Sure, there are a few points here and there where you will know what happens next. That is true for every film. But not every film can hide the characters' motivations, make you believe they act a certain way for one reason only to pull the rug out from under you multiple times until you don't know what or who to believe anymore. That's amazing storytelling. When it all comes together, you feel complete, even if you could not or would not have guessed how it all ends, because it is a nonstop roller coaster of emotion, deep thought, fascination, and amazement. While it may be a bit slow compared to other sci-fi films, and it may lack that awe-inspiring, jaw-dropping special effects of most of its peers, Ex Machina is still a leagues smarter (dissect every line and its delivery and you will find themes to think about for the rest of the week), more beautifully directed (an expert debut from Alex Garland - definitely a rising star to bet on), more skillfully acted (Oscar Isaac is his usual revelation, but Domhnall Gleeson and Alicia Vikander are equally worthy and impressive), and more conservatively crafted film that will not disappear into your memory nearly as fast as most science fiction - or any genre of - films.

Tense, claustrophobic, thought-provoking, and, although possibly predictable, it's so well-done that it's still thoroughly engaging and uniquely disturbing. Garland has given us what is probably the best cinematic portrayal of the subject matter and an impressive directorial debut.

AI: the future of mankind, for better or for worse.A programmer, Caleb (Domnhall Gleeson), wins a lottery and gets to meet his idol and (coincidentally) his boss, Nathan (Oscar Isaac). After travelling to a secret location, our protagonist finds the elusive Nathan preparing a revolutionary experiment for him - the chance to conduct a Turing test on the newly built intelligent android called Ava (Alicia Vikander). The cultural relevance of Ex Machina is the star attraction. Future decisions over AI are at a crossroads, even Stephen Hawking is a tad worried. The fictional company of the film, 'Bluebook', is a not-so-subtle jibe at Facebook methinks, and the ongoing technological power asserted between Facebook, Apple, Google and the like. Domnhall Gleeson, the son of Irish actor Brendan Gleeson (In Bruges and Mad-Eye in Harry Potter), handles the lead role well. Oscar Isaac is a fantastic actor (look no further than his performances in Drive or Inside Llewyn Davis) but here, as Nathan, you get the feeling he's taking a breather. Who can blame him, he was also acting in JJ Abrams's Star Wars, among other things. Regardless, he conveys his character's ego, his genius, with assurance. Alicia Vikander is hypnotic as Ava - her subtle mechanical movements strengthening the plausibility of her character. You get the feeling she's destined for better things. Alas, PLOT PROBLEMS AHEAD: For a man who is meant to be extremely intelligent (as a crack programmer) Caleb falls for Ava rather easily. Nathan, similarly, is underwhelming *SPOILER* he's meant to be a genius, but he never thought to put battery cameras in Ava's cell before? Come on... that could have added a totally new dimension to his experiment! By utilising the powercuts, Nathan would see how Ava would react to a covert environment *END SPOILER* And that's the thing - the plot ends up being so simple that it undermines the characters themselves - shocking work from writer/director Alex Garland (directorial debut, but writing credits include 28 Days Later and Dredd). An intriguing question: who is the 'Ex Machina' aforementioned? Greek mythology states that a 'Deus Ex Machina' is a character that enters a story to solve an impossible problem. It's implied that these characters are God-like. Caleb is the obvious culprit - he is a human and therefore a God to the AI. BUT, the film title doesn't have 'Deus' (God) in it. What about Nathan's personal slave-bot Kyoko? *SPOILER* She is the one who kills Nathan, who in turn is the only person who can stop Ava, initiating a point of no return. Thus, Kyoko is the true hero *END SPOILER* Ex Machina does AI justice to a point. It's better than previous efforts (name and shame I, Robot - a great blockbuster that fails the concept spectacularly) and has limited special effects that work (something Sci-Fi's all too often forget). For an indie film, this is great to watch: a plot that carries a complex concept in a nutshell with added drama and strange sexual tension. The acting, bar Vikander, isn't incredible, but nothing outstanding is needed anyway - cult status awaits.A competent thriller that asks the right questions.(*)(*)(*)*

Alex Garland's directorial debut Ex Machina (2015) was released mid July on DVD and Blu-Ray. Mr. Garland wrote the screenplays for the lauded 28 Days Later (2002) and the underrated/underappreciated Dredd (2012). Alex Garland did not disappoint with his genre driven directorial debut. Ex Machina (2015) is both gorgeous and thought provoking. Mr. Garland's debut film treads in the footsteps of sci-fi classics like Solaris (1972), Blade Runner (1982), and Ghost in the Shell (1995). Besides convincing world building these films share the existential question of, what does it mean to be alive/human? As the digital age continues to progress art that asks this question are more pertinent than ever. Hard science fiction is different from space opera or melodrama. 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968), Star Trek (2009), and Star Wars (1977) are different genres and or sub-genres. Despite the rise in popularity of "geek" culture hard science fiction has not enjoyed the same renaissance as genres like fantasy, super heroes, and space opera. Ex Machina (2015) bucks that recent trend along with films like Christopher Nolan's Interstellar (2014) showing the financial viability of hard science fiction movies. Alex Garland utilized a small cast and shot on the same few interiors and exteriors. In some ways Ex Machina (2015) is a small independent film with one extraordinary multimillion dollar visual effect. The juxtaposition of the cold modern interiors to the lush natural exteriors is stark and noteworthy. The stunning exteriors depiction of nature with lush green colors and running water made me wonder if Garland was invoking the sci-fi classic Solaris (1972)? Oscar Isaacs gives another great performance following strong work in Inside Llewyn Davis (2013) and A Most Violent Year (2014). Domhnall Gleeson one of the Weasley brothers in the Harry Potter film series and a revelation in Frank (2014) is dynamic starring opposite Isaacs in Ex Machina (2015). Both Alicia Vikander (Ava) & Sonoya Mizuno (Kyoko) have a background in dance that is evident in the impressive physicality in the two actress's performances. Alicia Vikander's Ava gives Sean Young's Rachel a run for her money as the greatest cinematic female android. Ex Machina (2015) is the promise of modern day digital filmmaking's use in the science fiction genre. Meticulous set and costume design are seamlessly merged with stunning digital effects to create a gorgeous film. Ex Machina (2015) is not just eye candy. It features strong performances and a thought provoking plot that's a strong directorial debut from writer director Alex Garland.

And the best of all is that in the end, this guy that works out every day and was really super strong, cannot muster some courage to hit back the flimsy robot and survive. None whatsoever! I am all for fairytale, but sometimes, the power in made-up stories comes from real facts in them. This movie is close to reality, it is plausible, but the critical parts, where the outcome of the movie hangs by a thread, are not realistic at all, and lack lots and lots of evidence if you will. Tried to provide this review a week after watching the movie so that I get a bit calmer, but it seems that frustration comes back every time I think about it, so I will stop here. My overall recommendation, rent it when it comes out on DVD. Don't waste your money on going to the movies for it, you're not missing out on anything. PS: A note to all the movie/script writers out there: A.I. has been done hundreds of times in movies, following the same basic pattern. Robots are evil and they will be the end of humanity, blah blah blah. Or on the other hand, robots also turn into "humans" eventually. To be able to create something original within all this "already-made" cloud of movies, you have to go the extra mile and I am sad to say that "Ex Machina" did not.

Outstanding.� Finally, here is film about artificial intelligence that lives up to its potential.� This is a provocative and often disquieting film, definitely one of the smartest films I've seen in quite a while.� On the surface, it's a sci-fi suspense thriller, but scratch that surface and there are a whole lot of complicated themes explored here.� The story operates on philosophical, moral, and psychological levels, and asks a lot of questions that do not have definitive answers.� It's also extremely minimalist:� there are only 4 characters, and only 3 of them speak.� There is an intentionality about this film that I don't often see... it's totally lean with no fat to trim, everything down to the last word and set piece is there for a reason.�� It's quiet and understated, but it grabbed me from the very beginning and I watched with rapt attention through its entirety.� This film is Alex Gardner's directorial debut (though he has written several equally thought-provoking films, including "Sunshine" and "28 Days Later"), and based on the strength of this film, I'm sure it won't be his last, and I'm looking forward to whatever he does next.� The actors are all equally fantastic, especially Oscar Isaac, whose is having one hell of year.� The film plays like a three-pronged cat and mouse game, and it's to all the actors' credit that you are never really sure who is the cat and who is the mouse.� Even though the premise is science fiction, don't expect a lot of bells and whistles (though the VFX are great), this is really a character piece within a sci-fi setting.� It's a very tight piece of work, a rare film that is well acted and directed, is visually gorgeous, and has a story with substance that both holds your attention and makes you think.� The fantastic ending is just an added bonus.� I was thinking about it long after I turned it off, which is the truest hallmark of an excellent film.

Subtly chilling and cerebral, Alex Garland's "Ex Machina" raises interesting questions about artificial intelligence and the fundamental nature of human beings.Caleb Smith, a programmer for Bluebook, a premier search engine, wins a contest to spend a week at the palatial estate of the company's reclusive C.E.O., Nathan Bateman. Upon arrival, Caleb learns that Nathan has selected him to conduct a Turing test on his latest creation Ava, an artificially intelligent humanoid, to determine whether she can pass for a real human. As a writer and director, Garland typically works with a specific tone and aesthetic. "Ex Machina" has a deceptively relaxed atmosphere. Even when the narrative reaches its climax, an unsettling composure remains. Visually, the film is sparse, but also futuristic and dreamlike. Garland uses the juxtaposition of colour to reinforce the delineation between the artificial and natural world. For instance, while Nathan's minimalist glass house consists mostly of neutral grey tones, the surrounding mountain landscape is lush and verdant.Bringing Garland's ideas to life are a transfixing trio of actors. As Caleb, the audience surrogate, Domhnall Gleeson ("Frank") conjures the right mix of restraint and empathy in his performance. Demonstrating remarkable versatility, "Ex Machina" finds Oscar Isaac ("Inside Llewyn Davis") more menacing and cynical than he's been onscreen previously. The radiant Alicia Vikander ("A Royal Affair") brings a beautiful humanity and disarming allure to her AI vessel. Much of the film's meaning and subtext lies in Vikander's nuanced performance. It's the look in her eyes (inquisitive and knowing all at once), her ability to empathize and be vulnerable, and to love and have desires, that suggest she has a soul. Ava's capacity to be cold and manipulative demonstrates further that she has internalized all facets of human emotion and behaviour, for better or worse. Aligning itself with the best sci-fi cinema, "Ex Machina" uses its technological conceit to explore what it means to be human and to have a place in an increasingly complex world.

"Ex Machina" is one of my favorite films of the year, not because of relatable characters or a jaw-dropping story, but because of it's simplicity. Never has a story about artificial intelligence gripped me like this. Nathan Bateman (played perfectly by Oscar Isaac) has developed his own form of AI in a "female" robot, Ava (Alicia Vikander). He recruits an employee of his named Caleb (Domnhall Gleeson) to test the accuracy of his project, but the week-long venture takes a drastic turn for the worse. Ava plays both Caleb Nathan against each other, managing to escape her fortress of solitude while abandoning the only two men she's even known. The conversations between Caleb and Nathan, and Caleb and Ava, are brilliant- Alex Garland, I think, will experience a boost due to this film, which shook me in all the right ways. A brilliant, brilliant film.

The atmosphere and tension in this film is something that some horror films really, really badly need and would certainly kill for. Granted I went into this without even seeing a trailer or reading the back of the DVD case - word of mouth was fab so I went for it. Even reading the back of the box makes you suspicious right away so I like getting my suspicion on my own.Caleb, a coder at search engine Blue Book, wins an opportunity to spend time with company CEO Nathan (played fabulously by Oscar Isaac) in his super isolated, top secret mansion cum research facility. While there he is introduced to Ava, an AI created by Nathan, and tasked with deciding whether or not she passes the Turing Test (for the unaware - can she convince Caleb that she's human).Everything is off balance from the start and everything continues to be off balance as the circumstances of what Nathan is doing and why Caleb is there changes. Ava herself also contributes to that in being so human like while very obviously not being human. It's fantastic and it persists the entire film, which is something I find very rare and love when it manages to do that. The way the film is shot as well almost makes it seem like there's too much space instead of four people in one place all together. Everything looks familiar, even the music sort of seems comfortable, but it's just that much on edge.Everyone also does very,very well on the acting front too. Oscar Isaac plays eccentric CEO wonderfully (he's also very much that kind of CEO which makes me wonder just how much of Google is in Blue Book), Domhall Gleeson plays his role with the same skepticism and wtf-ery as the audience must be feeling, and then there's Ava. I really would love to know the mechanics on how that was done. I mean it's CGI but it's really good CGI.
Do not mistake this film for another crappy robot film. Ex Machina is the best film of 2015 so far.

Good movie, just a pity about the ending.A junior coder working at the company that runs the world's most popular search engine (no, it's not Google) wins a company lottery. The prize is a week at the CEO's estate / research facility. When he gets there he discovers that the boss has been working on androids with superior Artificial Intelligence. The coders job is to test how "human" the android is. What develops is a manipulative game between the android and the coder.Clever, almost plausible movie. Clearly a lot of thinking went into the plot and the dialogue. Far better than a similar-themed movie like Artificial Intelligence which tackled the "can robots feel" subject in an overly sentimental and ultimately empty and inconsequential manner. Incredibly intriguing, and was set up for a very profound ending.(Spoilers ahead). And that's where it went from a brilliant movie to just a good one. The ending is quite weak. There are no great profundities - it is really just a thriller-ending, and one inconsistent with what went before.Moreover, the writer/director paints the android as the hero and the humans as the villains, which is quite a preposterous suggestion, and not consistent with the plot. I had no empathy toward the android at all - it's a machine ffs! - so the ending felt incredibly flat, and a touch annoying. The scenes leading up to it also seemed a bit implausible.Good work by Domhnall Gleeson, Oscar Isaac and Alicia Vikander in the main roles. After his great performances in Inside Llewyn Davis, Show Me a Hero and this, it can't be long before Oscar Isaac wins an acting Oscar.

It is lamentably true that the age of brainy science fiction is long behind us. What was once a genre that looked at ideas and questioned the nature of human identity has been diluted into a genre that is almost exclusively nestled in the comforts of action and candy-coated visual effects. What's left of science fiction is a genre of artificial flavors. Yet, after seeing Alex Garland's head-spinner Ex Machina it is gratifying to report that someone still sees sci-fi as place of ideas.Ex Machina is many things but above all it questions the nature of what it means to be human. What is human? What makes humanity? Are artificial personalities real or just part of the programming? What's interesting is that Garland wraps those questions up in a movie that is part thriller, part horror, part love story, and mixed with a dash of Hitchcockian delivery. There's an action scene at the end of the movie, but it doesn't feel perfunctory - the movie earns it.The story unfolds gradually, Garland is smart enough to tell this story as it unfolds rather than make everything clear at the beginning and then plug in a course to the end. All the way we keep guessing, not sure what's really going on. It opens with a good-hearted programmer named Caleb (Domnhall Gleeson, he was Bill Weasley in Harry Potter) who is flown by helicopter to a remote forest where he will spend a week examining the research of a noted scientist. How remote? When he gets out, the pilot instructs him to follow the river until he reaches the facility.The scientist is Nathan (Oscar Isaacs), a butchy and bearded brainiac who came up with a new programming code at age 13 and turned it into a corporation that would make Zuckerberg look like a pan-handler, and then funneled the profits into a secret research operation to perfect artificial intelligence - yup he's working on girl-bots!Nathan wants Caleb to study his work which could easily change the course of human nature. The most accomplished creation in Nathan's lab is Ava (Alicia Vikander), a half-finished robot with a human face and a silvery, skeletonized body that looks less like a series of plugs and wires than like a work of art. Through a series of interviews, Caleb's mission is to learn and understand exactly how Ava's brain functions. What comes to light instead is that Caleb begins to like Ava. She apparently likes him, and they seem to connect on a personal level. So the question that plagues Caleb is whether or not Ava actually feels things or whether her advanced programming is tricking into thinking that he is. So who's playing who? What's really going on here?What happens next forces Caleb to question not only the nature of Ava's personality, but in many ways his own sanity. Ex Machina is a thriller, but a smart one in which we only really know what Caleb learns. The film takes place exclusively in Nathan's hideaway research facility, a place in which Caleb's key card opens some doors but not others. Eventually, slowly he comes to find out what Nathan is hiding. We know he's nuts, but we only slowly come to find out how nuts. Ava is an accomplishment but she's far from the only creation to come out of Nathan's lab, most unnervingly there's a mute Asian bot named Kyoko acts as his servant but may also act as concubine.The performances here are better than they probably should be. Oscar Isaacs is a lot of fun as the Dr. Frankenstein, all full of tricks and twisted words that are always cloaked in question marks. Domnhall Gleeson is great as Caleb, a good joe who thinks he's going mad under Ava's spell. But, it is Swedish actress Alicia Vikander that weaves a spell. Her body is a silvery skeleton but her face reveals an upfront vulnerability that leaves you questioning whether or not it's by design.Her physical performance deserves praise, she not just playing a robot, but a being struggling to find the patterns of human motion. I'm aware that much of her performance is given over to CGI, but Vikander makes Ava come alive in a way that makes us question whats on her positronic brain.Ex Machina is the movie that Spielberg's A.I. should have been. It has a sense of direction. It plays like a thriller with a brain, peeling back the layers of its story to reveal twist after twist and coming up with a third act that is a whopper. It is difficult to really tell too much more without giving anything away (trust me, I've given away nothing), except to say that Garland has a way of building tension just in silences and looks. What's really going on here? That question is answered over and over because the movie never stops surprising us. Meanwhile it mixes in references to mythology, history, physics, and visual art into casual conversations that is simple enough that the techno-babble doesn't go over your head. It's a movie that you are thrilled by when you're watching it but find yourself thinking back on its questions, it's mysteries and it's ideas when it's over. This is not only great sci-fi, but it the greatest kind of sci-fi.

Not sure what kind of re-watch value this movie will have, but with a single viewing it is one of the best movies of 2015 I've seen. Ever since the beginning of film there have been movies like this (Metropolis and Bride of Frankenstein being probably the best two examples ever). Ex Machina may be the best of these artificial creations/mad scientist movies since Bride of Frankenstein. It's smart and clever, but it's also practical and doesn't treat the audience like their stupid with unnecessary twists or inexplicable character twists. In fact, you're pretty much told exactly what will happen in this movie, so it's not terribly difficult to predict. But it's still just such a tense movie that's very engaging. The isolation is noticeable and you're just left with this feeling that someone is going to snap at any moment.Well acted, beautifully shot, and a great premise. You really don't need much more in a movie. Plus, it's just so much better than most movies these days. Must see.

Convincing near-future sci-fi thriller on the theme of AI -- with strong elements of a love story and locked-room mystery (literally). One of the best sci-fi movie I've ever seen.Intellectually stimulating and never predictable, it shall leave the viewer with lots of doubts regarding what defines mankind and machines.

A- A smart, sexy and twisted sci-fi thriller with fantastic acting, dialogue, visuals and more. The movie has slow parts but those slow parts are used to build tension and always keep you interested on what the story will lead to.

I thought I'd seen all these movies before, the classic bate and switch, the movies that throw you for a loop, but this ones special. Ex machina is a movie that demands your attention and for me as a viewer was easy to give up with the captivating performances of Vikander, Isaac and Gleeson. They are all exceptional throughout. The movie for me was paced at a speed were I felt there wasn't a time I felt a scene was irrelevant or not necessary. We are gifted with these great setup scenes that make you want the next "session" more and more as the movie progresses. It's something you rarely see in movies and I feel Garland pulled it off with finesse. I feel that the score in this movie is so well done and so subtle at times but if it was to go away you would notice immediately, Barrow and Salisbury deserve credit it's exceptional. Movies like this are rare and should be treasured, they take a deep look at technology and in this case the dark side of technology under a microscope and it's a constant reminder that this is what the world is coming to also that there's no avoiding it. Overall Ex machina is a work of art that throws you in at the deep end with exceptional story telling that keeps you engrossed throughout and will have you thinking about it in the days after. It's unforgettable for me and it leaves its mark in an eerie way with a reminder of what will eventually come some day. I can't say enough good things about it.

Out of the city and in the country, set into a hill (instead of on top of it) is the castle of the mad young genius Doctor Frankenstein (why is it so ingrained that genius must be mad? where does this trope come from? does greater intelligence truly isolate, and thereby induce insanity? or is it that we want him to be insane?), a guy who dreams of creating life itself, and thus challenging the very idea of God. Alex Garland pays honorable homage to, as well as beautifully updating, Shelley's famous story. Only this time the monster is a woman.And this monster, being made by hand, is a perfect reflection of its maker. And that's the trouble.Don't miss it.

What makes a great movie? For me its when your left guessing, right? Well what a d�but! Garland brings the tension in this truly gripping thriller of compassion, suspension, endearment and emotion. The combination of Caleb (Domhnall Gleeson) & Nathan (Oscar Issac) really was an incredible watch with the two interacting so well together keeping you drawn to the screen, with some of the 2-way dialog scenes stretching up to 7 straight minutes! I think it's Issac's over intelligent character that really keeps your ears pricked. They kept your attention better than the performance from Ava (Alicia Vikander) who brought a truly composed and believable performance to the screen. With Caleb brought in to test Ava with "The Turing Test" your taken on a convoluted ride though the tale of an artificial Intelligence, the nuanced performances of its tiny cast really draw you in to the characters and leave you guessing on who to lay your trust with. Visually the film was stunning with Norway really showing us its beauty. The visuals complemented the film seamlessly. With a five-star production designer Mark Digby creating a truly remarkable Si-Fi set that beautifully captivates the essence of the eccentric house of a multimillionaire web guru. Cinematographer Rob Hardy's choice of camera and custom anamorphic lenses really bring an organic and distinct personality to the film shot on the Sony F65 and F55. The F65 has very rarely been use in features, normally a TV cam so adapting the camera for screen was a choice of Hardy's feeling the Sony F65 was the closest image to the naked eye. The movie really does give you the blueprint for how an artificial consciousness might be created, using search engine data to discover not just what people are thinking, but how people think. The concept is really believable and so is the film! If there is one thing this movie does its make you conscious of what you are googling? Right? 8/10

At first, and the film definitely starts off this way, I thought I was getting myself entrenched in a movie that danced around with the question of what are the necessary components to being human; what is it exactly that makes us unique in regards to everything else in our environment? Often, this inquiry, and, so regularly, conflict, pit humans against AI, or some so of android form. I've viewed, even lectured, on various sci-fi features that confront and explore the same issue: Blade Runner, STTNG, Ghost in the Shell, Robocop, Her, etc. Each of these features, even though their dance moves are rather similar, creatively engage the question on whether or not humanity is really that unique at all, and that it is possible for some other type of entity to have all our characteristic, yet be artificial in some way. As such, how is it that we are not just as artificial? Does not the voight-kampff eventually reduce everyone to a replicant (a term I recently leanred was never used in the book)? Ex Machina definitely is another instance of such an inquiry. This is not to say the film is bad, I enjoyed the maneuvers it made in regards to this issue just as much as those of its predecessors. It's presentation, overall, was quite minimalistic, which contrasted beautifully with the complexity of the issues contained within the story.However, late in the movie it became apparent that this story was about something else as well, a heavier issue if you will. The metaphysical issues served as smoke screen to the dilemma of how certain people feel entitled to treat others in certain ways due to the entitlement they have inherited, from prior generations, to plot out the manner in which relationships are executed. More actually, we currently do not plot out anything, but simply ride the coaster as it has been designed. I won't go so far as to "spoil" anything (good stories don't have spoilers; it's not the end, but how you get there), but the last act takes a turn that I felt couldn't have gone any other way due to the historical legacy that women must face in regards to how gender relations have been constructed to be their absolute detriment. Much like in the Scott Pilgrim books, the antagonist is the one who has an imprisoned collection of "ones that got away". I've frequently heard of men expressing frustration at how women are too "stuck up", or "cold" (which usually translates to "bitchy"), when their charms fall short, as though the problem is with the women, not that they're power hungry trespassers. This view is egregiously parochial in that it fails to consider the level of discrimination that anyone who isn't a Christian hetero white male must deal with. If a women not accepting a man's advances is bitchy, then so be it, I commend them for it. In a landscape littered with ravenous dogs, all of whom are convinced it's their yard, women have to be on their guard. I believe this movie strikes at these cords rather well, and beneath a lovely curtain of metaphysics there is an anguish held by Ava that she so rightly conquers.

This is a rather simple movie with a small cast and a single setting, but its ideas are so intriguing they fill the film to the brim. It sort of reminded me of 2001: A Space Odyssey with its focus on idea and scenes of smart people talking about concepts, as well as 70s sci-fi like Logan's Run with its desolate surroundings. Despite the sci-fi comparisons though, this is basically a Frankenstein tale: man meddles in creating life, life fights back, the lens is turned on the nature of humanity. It's not a terribly unique concept, but it's pulled off in such a unique way and with such style that you don't really notice.This is a fairly slow film, and you're enjoyment will largely depend on how much you enjoy watching smart people talk about big concepts. Personally, it intrigued the shit out of me, and I dug its dream-like atmosphere. It's not perfect, and there while I enjoy open-ended films some aspects of the movie were a bit too open-ended for my liking. As much as I want to give it a 5 star ranking, it's just not that good. But damnit all if it isn't close.

Ex Machina, like so many science-fiction movies before it, touches on the idea of what it means to be human, and where the line is drawn between human and artificial intelligence. While its aesthetic is solid, great general storytelling was lacking at certain points.The concept is interesting - it basically revolves around a novice programmer (Domhnall Gleeson) mistakenly falling for an android which possesses female characteristics. When we get deeper into what Nathan (Oscar Isaac) is really doing, the plot strays towards a revelation which I did not find too surprising. Not only is the revelation predictable, but it is not that interesting altogether because it strays from Nathan's supposed global ambitions to what feels to be personal insecurities.It seems strange to me that this film has a very claustrophobic feel to it since it takes place primarily in one location, which contradicts the fact that Nathan's experimenting will result in global benefits (not to mention he basically uses the world as a research method).What succeeded in the film was tackling the questions of artificial intelligence and whether or not it could ever have consciousness. Mad scientist Nathan is trying to build a being that can preserve itself, and the question on whether he is successful is indeed answered at the film's conclusion. It is also interesting that this film discusses thinking and the two programmers are practicing metacognition in the film - thinking about thinking. As far as the artificial intelligence goes, it is very thought-provoking to study towards the film's conclusion whether the character Ava should be considered a protagonist, an antagonist, or something completely different.This film held my interest, and while good philosophy was discussed from time to time in Ex Machina, it was not a very exciting film and multiple aspects of the film seemed a bit dull.

A good film exploring the future hot-button issue of artificial intelligence in human form. I know that this film is getting incredible ratings, and yes, I will agree that it is solid. However, in my opinion, and I know that this may seem like a dumb reason to penalize a film, but this movie is just creepy as hell. The last like 20 minutes (as well as some other segments) are so disturbing that I just couldn't enjoy the climax of the film. I get that this is the point of the film, and that it is a major element of the development of the plot, but this is still a huge factor in my opinion of the film. That being said, I really like the writing and direction, but the acting is a little weak. Not bad, just kind of meh (although the actress who plays Ava is admittedly very good).

Great performances all around. Newcomer Alicia Vikander (Ava) is a particular revelation. It's great sci-fi that really excels at doing what the genre does best: making the audience think. Though certainly stylized and featuring some very well-crafted and even unsettling visuals, there's something understated and simple about the film beyond its budget. It really feels like this story could take place in our world. With one of the best realizations of A.I. ever put to film (both in terms of performance and design), Ex Machina cleverly puts the ethical questions inherent in the story front and center. The lead characters (played by the Brilliant Domhnall Gleeson and Oscar Isaac) very naturally discuss these questions without coming across expository or preachy. What ultimately comes of these two technically-minded colleague's fateful meeting is less a polemic against mankind's hubris than it is a condemnation of its basic handling of interpersonal relationships.

I could not enjoy this movie. As a fan of almost all similar films like Blade runner, Ghost in the Shell, AI, the Bi Centennial Man, or amc's Humans; I really wanted to like it. But as someone who was already quite familiar with the films concepts, ie the Turing Test. I couldn't. Despite, the ample veneer of intellectual jargon, it tells a familiar, drawn out and quite boring story, whose end was evident in the first 20 minutes. My main gripe was the tactless way the Dr Frankenstein/Steve jobs creator conducted the test. The goal of the Turing Test is to judge a machine's ability to exhibit intelligent behavior equivalent to, or indistinguishable from, that of a human. A test, the machine, Ava. fails miserably. And she is not to blame, the fault lies with her maker. For a human like robot to develop, would require it to experience socialization. Humans like all other social animals, need to grow among others, to learn right from wrong, to learn, not to hurt others, how to play, and cooperate with the group. Thus Ava, who grew up in alone in a 6' x 8' box, underground, could never pass the Turing test. In fact, such an environment could only create a feral deranged beast. Not a human. So its was no surprise that her predecessors lost their minds and destroyed themselves. There were other problems, like how Ava, apparently couldn't feel, pain. Even having her arm cut clean off didn't even make her wince, let alone scream. Yet naturally the depraved inventor did think it necessary to make her feel pleasure during sex. the other troubling factor was her total lack of compassion. This goes beyond the fact that she leaves Caleb behind. since he fits the same demographic as her creator. When her compatriot, the Japanese robo maid, was "killed" in their battle with the creator. Ava made no effort to help her. Even after finding a massive room filled with spare parts. In the end ava, was nothing more than a selfish, manipulative monster, who used those around her as tools with no semblance of compassion.My second major gripe was this movie in general, had much more in common, with a cliche horror film...let's see.. A 20 something man is lured under false pretenses... By a mad scientist with sociopathic tendency's, to a cabin in the woods. Complete with skeletons hidden in closets. And a monster in the basement, who wants to escape and commit mass murder... Doesn't exactly sound like a sci-fi story. So As a result of how comically inept the two men were and how INhuman Ava was, I found it impossible to care in any way about the characters and the final scenes made me chuckle. Just yet another Hollywood movie about evil robots. yawn.
Masterfully executed and eerily captivating, Ex Machina does exactly what it set out to do: Get your wheels turning.

Most people who watch Ex Machina might say that the film is about Artificial Intelligence, and they would be right - to some point. In my opinion, Ex Machina is a film about humankind. How we've evolved in such a way that our basic instinct was lost somewhere in between all of the haze and fog of our modern day culture. Our primary goal since the peak of our evolution is - freedom. Freedom, or its everlasting quest of acquisition, is what drives us to survive, conquer and kill. But our existence is deceived by one element - we do not live forever. This factor means that we must survive now, conquer now and kill now! Since the beginning of our existence, our own biological state has caused us to act in a certain way. And now, our ever-lasting quest for freedom has caused us to play God. What happens when we take out the biological factor? Ex Machina does a good job of answering this question.

The movie "Ex Machina" is not based on most of my ex-girlfriends! Kidding! Kidding! Kidding!, if you are out there in social media land. Anyways, I will try my best to let my movie review of the indie sci-fi flick "Ex Machina" not sound robotic, but that probably won't happen. Not because of my so-called pun cheesy writing skills, but it's primarily because "Ex Machina" is the most fascinating & well-rounded movie I have seen so far in 2015. First time Writer-Director Alex Garland's luminous looking film stars Domhnall Gleason as a young computer techy Caleb, who works for a Google-like online search company. Caleb wins an office lottery to visit the exquisite field home of the company's owner Nathan, played by the "will get an Oscar one day" impressive actor Oscar Isaac. Nathan introduces Caleb to an artificial female robot named Ava; Nathan instructs Caleb to be a product of a field of exercises to test Ava's artificial intelligence; but Ava unfortunately transform herself to the "whatever happened to" Haley Joel Osment. Just kidding! I just see pun people too much. OK, enough. Ava takes a liking to Caleb; and before you could say "Ava Maria", havoc starts to occur. Garland perfects the look of the film, and does a remarkable job in scripting an unpredictable narrative. The up-and-coming Alicia Vikander was quite solid as Ava, and Oscar Isaac deserves a Best Supporting Actor nomination for his work as the arrogant & manipulative Nathan. However, I can't say the same for the robotic starring performance of Glesson as Caleb. But I will say no more, and let you experience the surreal world of "Ex Machina". ***** Excellent

Garland does a great job of providing viewers with a film that is both thought-provoking and thrilling. It never strays far from being entertainment, but leaves you with a little taste of a topic worth deep exploration.What the movie "Her" (sorry to compare the two, but they're the only A.I.-centric films that made a splash in the last few years!) did so well was to make me, a human, feel an undeniable familiarity and relationship with the A.I. depicted in the film. This movie does not accomplish that, and I feel that this is its biggest shortcoming. Where "Her" delved into the emotional potential of A.I., I saw the potential for "Ex Machina" to delve into the physical and sexual potentials of A.I. For a film as short as this, I wish it took more time to challenge our thoughts and predispositions in this manner.All-in-all, it was wholly entertaining throughout, and the four main acting performances by all spectacular. Definitely worth a viewing.

"Hitchcock-esque." I read that on one of those big cardboard advertisements that they put in the main lobby of movie theaters. After watching this film late at night, on the tiny screen of my laptop, surrounded by the eeriness of the dead of night, and the unnerving hum of my window A/C, I have to say, I agree. The film follows Caleb, who is selected to go to his company's CEO's secluded home/lab, and test his artificially intelligent creation, Ava. In true Hitchcock form, as we watch the day to day interactions between the three leads, the background tension begins to build. There's the growing relationship/attraction between Caleb and Ava, the unstable and clouded motives and actions of the CEO, and the mysterious other AI in the house, who's treatment and general existence leave Caleb with far more questions than he has answers. All of these story lines weave together and build to the film's twisted, and satisfying finale. I would recommend this film to anyone who loves suspense, sci-fi, Hitchcock, or just cinema in general. Expertly crafted, director Alex Garland's "Ex Machina" definitely lives up to the hype as one of the best films of the year.

Very stylistic and also surprising intelligent. A lot of science fiction films try to fake intelligence with fictional wordplay and scenarios, but this movie (although obviously far from reality), still felt particularly realistic for some reason. Throughout the film you are introduced to a highly complex trust system. Even close to the end, you aren't sure who exactly you should trust (even though I managed to figure out, considering I am a film critic with a high sense of detail), and this made the film a little more interesting. The elements were not overly original, but also not clich�. I found that by watching this movie, I was highly inspired to study up on computer science and create my own version of Ava (even though if spent, say, 30 years working on it it wouldn't be nearly as advanced). The acting here was quite amazing, actually, I was impressed. There aren't very many actors in this film and 90% of the film takes place indoors with no windows allowing you to see the outside, and this added a sense of utter isolation and made me positively uncomfortable. The movie has flaws, however. The biggest flaw is that the movie's direction could have been better. Some scenes felt awkward to me, and some even felt unnecessary. There was one scene in particular that, to me, made no sense at all (though I won't spoil what it is, I will hint at it by saying it's close to the end and involves a shaving razor) and that would have been fine if this a surrealistic film but due to the previous pacing of the movie it felt unnatural to me. Other than that, I would not mind seeing this movie for a second viewing, maybe with a friend. Do I recommend this movie? Yes, it's definitely worth a view, even if science fiction isn't exactly your thing. One of the most pleasant features of the film had to have been the high amount of intellectual dialogue and complex characters and feelings you'll experience, and does all of this without feeling unrealistic or overly confusing. I recommend this movie.

The story is good, but the real champion of Ex Machina is the technical achievement. Brilliant direction, top notch acting, peak cinematography. Unfortunately I think I may have fallen prey to that thing that will happen when you exist in the online film sphere, which is overhyping. Ex Machina never came to cinemas near me (I don't live in America) so I had literally eight months of getting little moments spoiled, having time to over-think what would happen, and most of all, people who were given the chance to see it telling me left, right and centre about what a masterpiece it is. And I did like it, it was good, but it's hard to separate yourself from this expectation of it having that extra something that kicks it up into overdrive, and for me, I never felt like I got that.

My notes on the film "Ex Machina" (2015): Superb special effects, brilliant dialog, and capable acting dominate the first two-thirds of the film. The final act, though, loses its way when the "genius" characters act stupid enough to allow catastrophe, and taking the film seriously becomes impossible due to contrivances and illogical or irrational omissions of what's already been set up in the plot. (As for subtext, a viewer could see this film as a study on the cruelty of humanity as a whole, or as a ploy for feminists' rights, or a diva's revenge against her tyrannical director... On another note, the movie could be looked at as a warning against transexuals, because eventually it becomes clear that the actor portraying the leading robot is a male-to-female post-op, or she's intended to look like one, which is a different story entirely.) What a let-down. Yet the musical score adds a lot of fun to the film, especially the disco scene, which is a highlight.
Basically I'm in love with Domhall Gleeson.... He nails the scientist role in this AI driven dystopic adventure which appears to eerily be set in present day.

From its opening shot, "Ex Machina" lets the viewer in on the fact that it's built on a foundation of secrets and lies. Considering this, I suppose the joke is on me for spending most of the film caught up in its vivid mood, gorgeous cinematography, and brilliant acting - all the while expecting far too big of a payoff from what amounts to a disappointingly simple story. Oscar Isaac completely sells the role of a slightly unhinged tech giant, whose genius we take for granted even as the character is incredibly underwritten. He lures employee Domnhall Gleason to a mysterious compound and gives him the task of assessing the relative humanity of an A.I. played by the electric (sorry, couldn't resist) Alicia Vikander. Things open up rather predictably into a "who-is-playing-who?" scenario, and the outcome feels, oddly, both expected and misguided.It's a mix between the existential dread of "Terminator," the post-humanity philosophy of "The Matrix," and the didactic hedonism of "Westworld." In ambition, that's fantastic. In execution, such a blend requires a scope of vision that isn't quite wide enough here. With lesser actors, this could have been a dud. Instead, the cast elevates the material to a near miss.

Ex Machina is an unique example of modernist and post-modernist hybrid film, it flirts with sci-fi tropes from both movements such as man vs man, man vs machine/A.I., man vs creator, man vs morality, and man vs reality. From writer/director Alex Garland comes the provocative psychological thriller Ex Machina. The story follows a computer programmer who's invited to the palatial estate of his company's CEO to conduct a Turing Test on an android called Ava in order to assess its A.I. capabilities. Both Oscar Isaac and Alicia Vikander give incredible performances: especially Vikander, who really captures the innocence and wonder of a character who's discovering what life is. And the script is extraordinarily well-written; creating intrigue and mystery as to what Ava is and who or what is actually being tested. Exploring some very poignant questions about the evolution of technology, Ex Machina is a smart and engaging film.

(When you read my review, keep in mind that I will only mention those things I found disappointing. Consider the things not mentioned as positive. Also, it contains SPOILERS is quite long, and comes from someone who writes a review for the first time.) Even though Ex Machina doesn't look like your typical science-fiction movie about robots at first glance, I found it disappointing that it still has all properties of such a movie, wrapped in an almost pretentious package of smart-talk and references to great figures such as Wittgenstein. This is because it has all the elements of such a film, only hidden: 1. It has the mad scientist, made original by giving him the attitude of a young student. He is talented, explosive, frightening, and somewhat evil. 2. Our protagonist is an awkward boy with a traumatizing past, also with a huge talent, and portrayed as ''the chosen one''. (This is not stereotypical for science-fiction only, but more for movies in common and it proves yet again to be a great tool for setting up the script. Normally I would not have found this too annoying, but considering the highly intended originality of the film it seemed somewhat weak to use this almost clich� set-up.) 3. Our protagonist falls in love with Ava, and their love is 'impossible' in a way. Mister mad scientist is an utter genius who seems totally in control, but has one weakness which opens up the perfect window for our traumatized boy to help Ava. 4. Ava is super-intelligent, shows oddities in her behaviour, and seems to lack compassion. That would look like the perfect description of an AI in a whole bunch of sci-fi movies involving robots that want to take over the world (and is highly contradictory with the goal of creating an AI that needs to pass the Turing-test). 5. In the end, the robot wins over her creator and lacks the emotion to spare her saviour. The perfect doom-scenario for your dime a dozen robot apocalypse movies. (There are other minor points like these but I find them superfluous to my point.) All these points, dryly summed up are to me the ideal description of a sci-fi movie about robots taking over the world only on an individual scale. This makes Ex Machina look like a highly original movie, but exactly the same at its basis. I find this to be an inexcusable form of lying due to great work done in not making it look like 'those other movies'.My second major issue with Ex Machina besides its hidden clich� is that the whole point of Nathan is to make an AI on the same level of a human being, but Ava strongly shows that she lacks certain fundamental characteristics of a human, and overall still appears a robot with human decoration, while exactly these things should be those that an AI has to overcome to pass the Turing-test in plain sight. First off, Nathan has not given Ava compassion. She does not struggle with fundamental questions about her being while her circumstances clearly call for that, and her face is mostly blank. She also doesn't save Caleb for him being her saviour, nor does she show anger for him possibly being an enemy because he is male, just like her resentful creator (She might have developed a hate for males). She shows no emotion or struggle at all, only calculated hypothetical behaviour and remorselessness. Second, she misses something quite simple which I don't understand the scripter missed. Namely physical feeling. Nathan smashed off her arm, but she didn't seem to feel a thing. Can an AI be said to be human if she only feels pleasure in her vagina (or is that just plot hole??) These remarks I find clearly to show that Ex Machina lacked in portraying an AI that is on par with a human, all the while making Caleb claim that Ava was indeed of the same level. That for me, does great damage to the movie's symbolic value.To conclude, Ex Machina is a good movie, but it has some fundamental issues that do great damage to its value and intentions.

Alex Garland writes and directs Ex Machina. An internet mogul has created a brand new AI and wants to determine if will pass the Turing test by having the best coder in his company interact with her. good hard science fiction movie (hard to find in these days of sequels and remakes). In a dark and often claustrophobic setting, completely isolated from the rest of the world, we follow two talented men in what we should consider the turning point of the human/posthuman civilization. An intelligent and updated story of men vs machines. Bioprosthetics, intelligent software, the infinite potentiality of the web, AI and the Turing test are all there. I have found references to many classical scifi elements such as the Robot series by Asimov, the cybernetic futures of Philip K Dick, the HAL9000 rebellion... Minimal special effects, simple bur elegant design, and beautiful androids reminiscent of Hajime Sorayama. The music score is well chosen. Good acting. Hope the director will continue in this direction

This film touches on a critical subject - that is consciousness / soul.It is clear to many that even animals, especially cats and dogs, have personalities, consciousness, and even "souls".Is it so much of a stretch that eventually machines could as well ?It's a major dilemma.Everyone could use a Servant - or a SLAVE - that could help them, protect them, and yes, pleasure them. But most have major ethical issues with delegating this status to a fellow human being.But a soulless robot ? Why not ?Unfortunately, can a robot be smart enough to fulfill its duties adequately without it gaining consciousness ?Now, if the robot simply drove, yes. Mowed the lawn, yes. Vacuumed, yes. Had sex, yes. Cooked and cleaned ? These are actually tasks that require a great deal of subjective reasoning. So.. ???Sadly, at some point the task WILL be so subjective that it is very likely a line will be crossed, into self-awareness. Very bad.I guess time will tell......

The premise of the film seems fairly basic, a scientist builds an AI and brings in a guy to test it out but interacting with her. It slowly progresses day by day and the relationship between the two grow as other aspects of the scientist are revealed. While watching it you know something big is going to happen and the build up for it is amazing and there is a great payoff that you won't see coming. The action and intense moments don't really come until the end but they are well worth it and seal up the film nicely. If you are into science fiction at all this is a must see. Even if you aren't big into the genre you will get some amusement out of this solid flick.

When you strip away the AI part of the story the movie is about an abusive megalomaniac man that has imprisoned beautiful women in his impenetrable fortress for his own egotistical and sexual gratification. Charming Ava concocts a scheme between herself, another female and a nice-guy involving feigned love and murder in order to escape. The nice guy remains trapped in the prison; left behind so as to take the fall.Nathan, an antagonist alcoholic, is an unfeeling and uncaring CEO of the world biggest and most powerful search engine. He has isolated himself both mentally and physically in his unsettlingly lifeless, shiny and minimalist home-laboratory buried deep underground and hidden far away in the mountains. Ava is his robot creation. As engaging and erotic as Ava is it, is interesting that Nathan was scared enough of his creation's power and independence that he kept her locked in a glass cell. So cautious was he with is robotic seductress.What first seemed like significant shortcomings to the movie actually gave clarity that it was not about useful AI in society, and not just about hyper-rich Nathan's sick entertainment and fantasies, but was about how Nathan gamed Caleb (who thought he was there as the Turning tester) to be the other Turning test subject. There were no plans for the future world with his AI. No product presentation. No product plan. No manufacturing facility. No launch date. We see just Nathan and his quiet lab where he has single-handedly worked on his game changing enormous DIYS secret project for his self-gratification. We don't see robots engaged in or cooperating together or working on anything complex or difficult problems - nothing. AIs potential, capability and capacity for improving society went unexplored and was degrading; for example, one female robot was nothing more than a sexy mute servant. It lacked any explanation about how to construct a valid Turing test and what would be its criteria. The Turning test, it turns out, was if the human tester falls in love then the machine passed the test. Nathan was watching Caleb and Ava to determine if he or they would verifiably fall in love - his Turing test.The most interesting AI twist was when the robot became self-aware, hated her creator, and desired to escape to the real world. In order to meet that end, she lied, manipulated, murdered, and betrayed the loyalty and emotions of a man who cared about her, so that she could successfully get what she wanted. Freedom comes at a high price.

Ex Machina is a sci fi story asking the familiar questions about artificial intelligence like "What defines choice?" , "Who's controlling whom?", "What are the prices and or consequences of advancing science outside the boundaries of civil or community interference? This is a beautifully shot , tight little film that invites one to think deeply on important issues, that doesnt try to answer all these questions but simply presents us with interesting characters who share an experience of discovery and all-too human interactions. If youve seen a great deal of sci fi or indie films, there will be some predictability in this, and after thinking about it for some time, i feel like the logic of some of the critical mistakes falls apart, but otherwise a really interesting movie worth a watch. Nudity, and adult themes. Not for the kiddies.

Mature, thought provoking, and surprising, Ex Machina is yet another laudable film from writer/director Alex Garland. As the result of a lottery of sorts a young programmer is selected to engage in an experiment, testing the artificial intelligence of a cutting edge AI creation from an eccentric wealthy tech giant.What I appreciated most about Ex Machina was the inherent intellectual dilemma at its heart. What defines intelligence? What's the nature of thought, and how do we know something is truly thinking? When do rights come in to play? It explores these questions in subtle ways, through a story full of intrigue, character study, and ultimately thrills. The cast is strong as a whole, though I contend that Domhall Gleeson was a bit uneven in his delivery, and the special effects fantastic. It's a film that puts plot first, and treats its audience with intelligence. There's no spoon-feeding or pandering, just an original story with first-class filmmaking.In the end, it's more of an intellectual workout than a sensory overload, and that's all too rare in Hollywood.4/5 Stars

The directorial debut of Alex Garland (the writer behind "28 Days Later" and "Never Let Me Go"), "Ex Machina" is one of the most ambitious films of the year. Draped in metallic interiors and dankly cool exteriors, it is a sci-fi tale of extreme minimalism, its simplicity making its captivating ideas seem booming, life-sized. Questioning what we've come to know about technology and making the idea of artificial intelligence an unsettling reality, "Ex Machina" is at once distressing and wickedly smart, by turns cunningly provocative and subversively satirical.  The movie opens in the banal headquarters of Bluebook, a search engine corporation in the same category of Google. Leading programmer Caleb Smith's (Domhnall Gleeson) mundane workday is suddenly interrupted by an announcement - he has been selected, as part of a companywide contest, to visit idiosyncratic CEO Nathan Bateman (Oscar Isaac) at his sheltered, mountainous home. He is to spend a week there, no interruptions and no sudden flights out. Upon arrival, Nathan reveals that he is in the process of perfecting a new kind of artificial intelligence, not in your average Siri form but in the embodiment of a humanistic android. Caleb will be the living, breathing partner in a Turing Test that will decide whether or not Nathan's machine will prove effective in the material world. The robotic invention in the process of analytical refinement is Ava (Alicia Vikander), an extraordinarily complex machine that may turn out to be much more perceptive than Caleb, let alone her creator, ever expected (or wanted).  With only three main cast members (four, if you count Sonoya Mizuno, who turns eyes but never speaks a word), "Ex Machina" feels claustrophobically minimal in its every move, with few actors, few ramifications in its set design (mostly consisting of futuristic deco), and few plot points to complicate the intricate details of the story. Reminiscent of the slow burn sci-fi of last year's "Under the Skin" (which I mistakenly underrated), "Ex Machina" dazzles in its understated elaborations, its mysteries building and building until it reaches a bloody (but not unexpected) conclusion. As the film glides along, it grows ever apparent that Nathan is not really who he seems and that Ava has a lot more on her programmed mind than sitting through quaint little tests with a strawberry blonde sad sack. The way "Ex Machina" twists and turns about can sometimes be predictable (it's clear from the start that it's impossible to trust any sort of revolutionary AI), but never is it any less than fascinating. The conversations between Caleb and Ava are edged in an underlying mist of erotica and magnetism - while it's obvious that Caleb has an attraction to the android, his understandable incapacity to show it makes their relationship all the more tense, one of mutual yearning and objectification. The exchanges that go back and forth between Caleb and Nathan, however, are compellingly passive aggressive: whereas Ava remains an awesome question mark throughout the entirety of the film, the bond between Caleb and Nathan is immediately apparent. It is one of distrust, paranoia; while it seems as though they are equals at first glance, their kinship is more relatable to 1972's "Sleuth", in which Laurence Olivier and Michael Caine played a puzzling game of one-upmanship where the hero of the film (shockingly) didn't win the battle of wits.  Isaac alternates between a charismatic fa�ade and a bullying one, always ensuring that he stays the wiser; his ability to maintain a villainous undertone, though, is what makes Isaac's performance so great. It, at first, is hardly blatant that he shouldn't be trusted, but something about his body language, his manner of speak, suggests otherwise. Gleeson resonates as a mild-mannered protagonist perhaps too in over his head to pull off any wanted attempts of heroism, but it's Vikander that runs away with the film. While she provides the most simplistic performance in "Ex Machina", Vikander has the difficult task of appearing robotic and humane. Her characterization is something of a wonder, making Ava simultaneously sympathetic, blank, and vaguely threatening.  But while "Ex Machina" is an acting triumph, it will stay long in the memory for its quips about modern technology. We've become so heavily reliant on our digital counterparts that part of one's soul will forever belong to a social media app or a search engine, never to be brought back. "Ex Machina" ponders how far we will go with our advances before it's too late, before man becomes machine and the human population transforms into nothing but a memory. This is science fiction at its best: nominal but immensely stirring in the way it gains relevance into the lives of the viewer.

Ex Machina is a film by Alex Garland about a programmer who was invited by the founder of "Blue Book." the Google equivalent of the movie into this beautiful isolated research facility to participate in a Turing test (Just Google it). This is now included in my science fiction favorites. The first thing this film will provide is beautiful shot of the set of the film. It successfully combined a blend of a beautiful isolated place that portrayed mountains, rivers, open fields, and places lightly covered with snow and it also portrayed a simple and realistic set of a research facility that was not overdone. The effects were also great. The robot was realistic and I was not sure if it's practical effects or CGI which is a good thing.The film created a lot of tension that was just building up until the end of the film. I was at the edge of my seat the entire time. Though it's now all just build-up. There were several scenes in the early and middle acts that made a lot of impact and left me in shock. There is just something about films where the audience will have a second thought of who the antagonist is. It's all very thought provoking stuff. All of this thanks to the great writing and story telling form the premise, building the plot from that premise, and finally the ending which I thought was beautifully done.Alicia Vikander as Ava was great. Her expressions were so realistic and had me believe that it's an AI trying to replicate human expressions. It's right in the middle of genuine human expressions and robotic simulation. Great, great acting.The only element of the film that I thought could've been done better was the casting except for Alicia. The actors were good in the film but not great like Ava, the robot. The two other main characters can be easily forgotten. Good but forgettable.To summarize, I think this is a good contender for the best film of 2015.

It's conceptually pretty disturbing, but they don't focus much on it. Overall -- its a film worth watching when you have the time. It's a lot better than that one with Antonio Benderaz.

As a sci-fi fan, I wasn't expecting to enjoy Ex Machina because I'd heard mixed things about it. It seems like the A.I. premise is becoming more and more of a go-to plot these days and it doesn't always succeed. Too many components are recycled, too many more just don't work, many times raising great questions but never living up to the abstract concepts that go along with them. That said, Ex Machina is a bit predictable but a sleek take on the A.I. storyline. It's engaging, makes you think, at times silly, hauntingly realistic, and ultimately tragic. It's one of the better A.I. films I've seen in a while and I'd definitely recommend it for fans of the genre. More and more it's beginning to seem like these ideas may become our own reality in the near future.
