This movie was not smart. It missed the mark on all fronts from the wholly incorrect characterization of the ?Turing Test? to the illogical and inconsistent (mis-)use of the term ?AI?. The audience is asked to take for granted such incredible innovations as perfectly-replicated human faces and emotions, while emphasizing the much less exciting aspects of what is otherwise completely mischaracterized as ?AI?.The acting was horrendous ? the pitiful dialog sounding like two actors reading through the script rather than actually interpreting it. The technobabble only made this worse, but you would think the actors would at least try to sell it more. For some reason, the characters are all supposed to be American, yet 100% of the primary actors are foreign, and their fake American English accents distract from the already-pitiful dialog. (The Irish guy can?t pronounce certain American phonemes, and the Swedish woman slips in and out of an American accent seemingly at random.) The protagonist Irish actor is also entirely the wrong casting for this role ? he is just not believable. But then again, the writing is so bad, it?s hard to put it all on him.Finally, the core plot really makes no sense, and if anything hand-waves all the core issues in favor of keeping us confused so they can surprise us with a couple of admittedly thoughtful plot twists. But they really seem to have just structured a story around a couple of plot twists, and lazily ignored all the back-story and sub-plots truly needed to carry it off. In the end, there?s really no well-defined motivation for the actions of the characters, and none of the twists is so good that I can read other commenters? reviews saying ?brilliant? and ?smart? without chuckling or even crying a little. In fact, this script would likely get a C in a college writing class, since we never get true motivation for the characters? actions. It?s as if the writer(s) are hoping to trick us into thinking they wrote something smart, by just leaving everything out and letting us as the audience guess as to the meaning. It?s the cinematic equivalent of looking at an ink-splatter in a museum and hearing someone talk about the deep meaning behind it, when you know it?s just a bunch of ink being flung at the canvas.The filmmaking is mixed, but on the whole falls woefully short of expectations. The special effects and cinematography are fine (some brilliant bits, but very few and far between) ? but that just makes the movie that much more disappointing when held up against the rest of the production and direction: long periods of up to 7 minutes of absolutely no dialog, and weird 60?s experimental style background music that makes you want to mute the volume until the dialog starts back up. The effects innovation that led to the believability of a "hollow woman? as a manifestation of the misnamed ?AI? is really pretty much the only innovation. The rest is just stock off-the-shelf, and could be set in any time period, with any lighting and design sensibility. This reviewer was left desperately wanting more in terms of special effects to support more scientific innovations and futuristic look and feel. This film just pushed all of that to the side, and focused entirely on the incongruous sexuality of a green screen.For all of you science fiction buffs out there who love to see new visualizations of futuristic technology and cool technical ideas, this is absolutely not the movie for you. If you are a horror buff (which I?m not), this is also not the movie for you ? it?s barely if at all really a horror flick. If you are attracted to the sexuality of the actors, forget it! Yes, there are some shameless scenes of exploitation of the female nude, but it even falls short of being even the softest soft-core. There?s just really no redeeming value that I can find. I?m sorry but you will be wasting your time if you watch this. I sure did!

This is the sci-fi films for you if you're into more of the science as opposed to fiction. Though, of course, a sentient artificial intelligence is also some pretty cool fiction as well. However, at least this sentient AI is something that's more relevant in this day and age as we get closer to achieving something remotely close to the artificial intelligence in the film. One of the film's main strengths is the fact that you're never really sure if you can trust anyone in the actual film, so that keeps things interesting as the narrative progresses which is, essentially, a test performed to see if Ava is truly a sentient AI or is it her programming? They do this by having sessions between Caleb and Ava where they discuss various issues. While these conversations themselves are immensely fascinating, as you get to see more aspects of Ava's personality and what motivates her, or what she pretends motivates her. But Caleb's and Nathan's conversations about all aspects of the project, the programming, coding and the debates they get into about the AI are, easily, the best parts of the entire film. I just find their conversations to be interesting and somewhat enlightening view into the mind of a genius, in the case of Nathan, a Steve Jobs-esque figure. There's the obvious religious symbolism with Ava being Eve from the creation myth, obviously, Caleb being a biblical name and Nathan being god himself. I don't think they hide this, but it's a little more subtle than what It was in It Follows. I don't wanna say the film is simple, because it's actually anything but, it is thought-provoking, but they do get a lot out of what is, essentially, a very minimalist approach to filmmaking and only a handful of actors. Granted, a lot of that is carried by the interesting conversations about the nature of artificial intelligence, how they'll look at us as fossils a couple of years into their existence, their thought process and whether they're sincere in what they say or if it's programming. The film does build to the climax that one would reasonably come to expect given the premise. But, and I don't know why, it wasn't exactly as satisfying as one would imagine. It has nothing to do with the execution of it, because I thought it was very well-done, but it just didn't really click with me as much as the rest of the film did. I just think it feels a bit out of place with such a high-concept film as this. It's definitely a contradiction. Cause it makes sense within the context of the narrative, but it still feels out of place. Still, I found the film to be excellent all-around. Great writing, really great acting and a great score. It might not be the most complex sci-fi film ever created, but it does offer and incredibly fascinating, and rewarding, look at AI and what may be a glimpse at our future. It probably won't be as dramatically interesting as this film, but sentience among AI is an inevitability. With that said, this film is highly recommended. I loved it.

Amidst a glut of AI-themed films in the past year, EX MACHINA is destined to stand out for what it does differently, and arguably better. While other films might be content to broach interesting questions in theory, they often lose focus by an over-reliance on visual effects and visceral action. This film strips much of that away and engages those interesting questions, often at the expense of emotional impact, but clearly aware of the implications of the subjects it addresses. The setup for the story is quite simple: a programmer (Domnhall Gleeson) for a large tech company is invited to the CEO's (Oscar Isaac) residence/research facility to perform a Turing Test on an AI he has created. From there, as director/writer Alex Garland says (or, at least pretty close), a small group of individuals are "put in a confined location, the screws are turned, and we see what happens." The central themes of human interaction and what it ultimately means to be human are key here, and addressed in an intelligent way with dialogue that sounds true-to-life. Although Domnhall Gleeson is essentially a stand-in for the audience, I found Oscar Isaac's character to be the most interesting. He was just so down-to-earth and personable, even as it becomes apparent that his motives might not be so altruistic. This leads to a sub-theme of manipulation, as each character manipulates and is manipulated by each other. There is even a brief scene which could lead to discussion about surveillance and the "internet of things," insofar as these large companies like Google have unprecedented access to our data and lives in general. Like all films of this caliber, there aren't really any answers given, but that really isn't the point. It's there to stimulate the mind and invite discussion. However, this means that it won't be to everyone's taste. The pacing is very deliberate and will probably bore some people. Also of concern/interest is the ending, which will likely divide even those who like the film. I thought it was shocking enough, but still anti-climactic in a way. Beyond the writing and performances, which were all excellent, the technical aspects of the film were equally impressive. I liked how the production design and cinematography worked together to create a sterile environment that you can take in with slow, deliberate camera movement and artfully composed shots that have perfect lighting. Even the robot effects were very well-done for something this modestly budgeted. If there's any complaint I have it's that the film, with a few exceptions, is as emotionally sterile as the controlled environment in which it takes place. I wish it had engaged a little more than just my brain. Still, all things considered, EX MACHINA is destined to become a sci-fi classic. It has intellectual themes and drama in a gradually intensifying situation, a great cast, and it looks great. What more could you ask for?

EX MACHINA A movie review by Mr. AnarchyMovie Review #1 Ex Machina is one of the best Sci-Fi movies I've seen along with Star Wars (IV, V and VI) and District 9. I've been itching and ready to see this for months now. This movie is beautiful, terrifying and this is a great example of what movies can do with small casts. Ex Machina doesn't waste our time with explaining too much on specifics in the beginning because let's face it we just wanted to see the damn robot. Caleb, Nathan and Ava are all well defined characters. Ava is a little more easy to understand since she's a robot. The story of a Caleb doing a Turing test on Ava is such a This is one movie you could count as something that which isn't tied to one genre. This could count as a neo noire because Ava is by definition a Femme Fatale. The robot aspect brings in the sci-fi element. But the ideas and philosophical questions that this movie asks are what qualify Ex Machina as being capable to put on a horror movie list. And don't misunderstand me, it's not that this movie is scary with jump scare or some sort of Five Nights at Freddy's thing, but rather it's more the possibilities of what could happen to the human race at the hands of our own creations should they turn on us. This movie looked beautiful in every aspect of the word. The lighting, the shots, the location and the special effects especially in Ex Machina were incredible. When the power went out I loved the red light in the room and how much it added to the atmosphere of the story. Then there was the cinematography, which was amazing all the way through. I was talking to a friend of mine and she told me about how much she loved this movie and how she loved the cinematography. She told me these specific words: "Every shot in the movie could be used as a single photo and look beautiful by itself." And, as far as I know, she's not a pretentious movie buff who dropped out of film school after not having the money to pay for the classes and I agreed with her completely on that point. Every shot of the movie looked great. I made one of the scenes in the movie my cover photo on my Facebook profile and they picked the best locations for filming Ex Machina. The special effects aren't the sole thing the movie relies on for effect, but I loved how Ava looked as a robot. I mean all of Ava looked mechanical enough to where we can believe that Ava is a robot yet not too mechanical to the point where it just looks ridiculous. If Alex Garland had a specific look in mind before he started filming then I'd wager that he achieved what he wanted. Now I will go onto the most depressing part of Ex Machina. While I maybe taking this part of the movie a bit too seriously, the ideas and questions introduced to us are both thought provoking and terrifying. And I think that they're important for me to talk about in this review. One thing I have to mention is that while this movie was going I paused it to get some food and I thought to myself: "Man, Artificial Intelligence is gonna kick so much ass when it arrives! I can't wait!" However after watching this movie ALL THE WAY THROUGH I realized that I was very wrong. A general question posed to us by the film is this: "Is A.I. safe and if not do we really want A.I. to exist?" Human beings are the Apex predators of planet Earth for many reasons one of which is that we've been making and using tools for hundreds of years. Human beings are responsible for creating the tool of language and that is one of our greatest achievements even though we don't all have the same language. But language hasn't turned on us or tried to kill us because it's just us tossing out sounds vibrations and pops. Those don't hurt us physically unless you're yelling straight into someone's ear like I do all the time so that I can make sure people can hear me. And (arguably) we as human beings have total control over this tool that we created. But Artificial Intelligence could be the death of us all solely because WE WOULD HAVE NO CONTROL OVER IT. Alex Garland gives us a worst case scenario for what could very well happen if we really created an A.I. capable of maneuvering on it's own without any additional programming, reprogramming, debugging, troubleshooting, etc. Ava was unpredictable to Caleb, toyed with his emotions, used her own technological misunderstandings to fool Caleb into thinking that she wasn't as advanced as he thought and when it came down to whether or not she liked him Ava really didn't give a shit about Caleb in the end. A gun, while in the hands of another man has the potential to kill, but it does not have the potential to get up, think for itself and kill us on it's own. A.I. has that potential and I don't want to go any further down the rabbit hole to see how this could turn out for the human race. All in all Ex Machina is a beautiful film. It was very well written and while the movie did have some rough points throughout where the storytelling could have been better it still came together in a beautiful way.

An outstanding, thought provoking film that's centered around the advancement of artificial intelligence. Ex Machina is stylish, well-acted and quite intense. It's also very unsettling, which is exactly what I want in a sci-fi thriller. I was so impressed with the performances, particularly Oscar Isaac, who I thought was absolutely brilliant in his role. It's a complex character that not anyone could pull off, but it's a performance that will stick with me. This is such a refreshing, smart film that mixes many different emotions. A fantastic sci-fi experience.

A very sparse yet interesting tale. The story depends on the viewer to think and read between the lines until the exposition provides enough details for you to get on board with the twists and turns. You never know exactly who to trust, who the primary antagonist or protagonist is until the very end. Thought provoking, interesting to think about as you watch, and with a nice twist at the end. I would have rated this higher, but the pace was close to being glacial. More forward motion and engagement of the audience would have been welcome.

This is one hell of a directorial debut for Alex Garland. You see, to me, sci-fis can go in one of two directions: awesome action thriller (Alien), great philosophical-intellectual type film (Interstellar, 2001: A Space Odyssey, etc.), and if a sci-fi tries to go both ways (Prometheus...), it does so at the expense of both ways and you end up with an average middle-ground, in my humble opinion. This film does the philosophical-intellectual thing really well. There are 4 things which make this film a great film: Oscar Isaac's character (very fascinating to listen to and watch; he's one of those really smart but definitely not nerdy geniuses, kind of like Tony Stark/Iron Man in a way) and Ava's character (brings a touch of humanity to the plate, ironically, as she is shown to be vulnerable but not all that she seems character), the dialogue and interactions between the characters (all of it, from the discussions on AI to aspects of life to what it means to be human, which is always a huge plus for me), the suspense towards the end and the twist, and the overall exploration of AI. The acting all around is great, the soundtrack, cinematography, and directing really set the mood very well, and the way we are shown things and how we gradually find out the explanations keeps you intrigued all through along with the great dialogue. There is a surprising amount of nudity, though, in this film, which kind of caught me off guard.There is only one slight weakness to the film, and that's Domnhall Gleeson's character. He isn't really fleshed out, and I feel like they had a missed opportunity to do that really well in the beginning, because throughout the film, you kind of just see him as this guy who's into AI, and nothing much more. What really made me notice this was because of how great Oscar Isaac and Ava were, so in that crowd, he stands out. Anyways, it's not really an issue. Just more of a missed opportunity for a perfect film.
Ex Machina is a heady, visually striking sci-fi treat featuring fine performances and an unsettling atmosphere.

Well, i think this Science Fiction film definitely has the warning of the year, "don't trust in humanoid robots".Maybe five months ago, when this picture was released for its first time, i was very eager to see it, because i felt trapped with the story. The British director and writer Alex Garland is technically unknow, so that could mean new ideas to the current cinema.Ex Machina is the story of a programmer working for Bluebook, the world's most popular search engine. Once there Caleb (the programmer) is impressed with the technological advances of Nathan, mainly with his most recent ceation, Ava.First of all, Alicia Vikander is amazing in her role as Ava, the A.I (Artficial Intelligence) prototype, and the two male protagonists are pretty convincing to, on the one hand, Oscar Isaac like the eccentric and talented Nathan Bateman, and on the other, Domhnall Gleeson like the innocent programmer Caleb Smith.This movie has a great cinematography by Rob Hardy (every detail is left to the viewer's eye) and the music by Ben Salisbury and Geoff Barrow is almost perfect, i can't explain how much my ears enjoy every chord.I enjoyed it so much, but i expect more. When a movie can make me feel something new, something so unique then it has to be a success. Unless that is the complete void left in my soul after seeing The Last Airbender. Ex Machina has done that and succeeds in that way and many more. From the beginning we're given one of the reasons this movie is captivating. The gorgeous landscapes. I'm not sure where Ex Machina was filmed but I want to go. The randomly inserted nature shots are like the best of the best from a discovery channel special. Obviously this is a somewhat trivial way to start off, but even if it was non-essential parts of the movie I found it worth mentioning just because it is SO pretty. (*ooh shiny thing*) Before getting to the meat of the movie, which is delicious I assure you, on the topic of pretty things it seems appropriate the visual effects. When initially thinking about the movie this was probably the last thing I thought about, they didn't strike me at one instance in the movie and make me go 'wow'. That's an enormous success for this particular movie. The fact that the effects blended so well with reality, that it is so convincing that you don't think twice about the weird skin/metallic body of Ava is a very impressive one (okay I thought twice, but only because it's weird, not to take note of the effects). The movie is not effects driven, but they have their place. Now that meat I mentioned. The movie is very simple. I might have to give a spoiler alert for explaining the basic premise because that could cover just about the first two thirds of the movie. Caleb is works for a company, whose boss has enlisted him to test out his super secret AI system he created. Testing involves simply interviewing the AI, which is named Ava. So it's lean meat, but the simplicity works because it allows the movie to fully explore the human (and non-human) interactions which are at the core (also gives time for more of those epic nature shots). The simplicity additionally lends well to the isolated atmosphere, which is essential. About those interactions. There are only three speaking characters in the movie, the three billed on the poster. Ava, the AI. Caleb, the one testing Ava. Nathan, the creator. The interactions are not dramatic, not excited, and not even particularly well written as far as sharp dialogue goes. While that could be a complaint, I appreciate it. Plain exchanges are the most reflective of reality. Plain presentation does not mean that the dialogue isn't engaging. In fact, it could be some of the most engaging dialogue I've seen in awhile. Contradictory maybe, but every single sentence takes on extra meaning and weight with the consideration of circumstances, who's talking, and what the words REALLY mean implicitly. In the way words so effectively advance the plot and enhance the way we view what is happening the dialogue IS well written. Absence of dialogue at times is just as effective here too. The dialogue literally asks plenty of questions to the characters, which is interesting enough on it's own. That being said these questions pose so many more implicit questions to the viewer about humanity and our psychology. It's absolutely fascinating how something completely inhuman exposes people as the most human they can be. Domhnall Gleeson as Caleb does the most talking and I have a hard time deciding if he is a strong or weak link in the acting here. While Issac and Vikander are undeniably great Gleeson is exceptionally plain. He fumbles with his words so often and they come out awkwardly that I can imagine having a real conversation with him in real life would be trying. Whether this is either poor execution of non-awkward lines, or fantastic execution of awkward lines it's irrelevant. The effect again adds to the reality of the movie. Oscar Issac plays the charismatic a-hole type, but still avoids what could have become a caricature. Vikander has the real challenge here and she is flawless. Playing an AI system she comes across as very human (which is the goal of the programmer), but *not quite*. It's so incredibly subtle I can't say what kind of nuances Vikander brought to it that made it such a compelling performance. It's not even comparable to typical depictions of androids in other media, that predictable stilted movement and speech. It's somewhere between that and human and it wavers in and out of the uncanny valley. The biggest and best part of Ex Machina is the atmosphere. The tone created here is stabbing intense without being overt or pushing itself on the viewer. Each scene sucks you in more. Dire and creepy for reasons I can't identify are a testament to Garland's direction. *Almost* everything about the movie is so subtle that explaining why and how something works or evokes certain reactions is a major chore, but it still does it damn effectively. Ex Machina is an astounding accomplishment that is equally spine-chilling and thought-provoking. Just like Ava is brought to a kind of intangible life, Ava--along with strong direction--brings intangibly uncomfortable life to the movie.***Bonus points to this movie for throwing in a fantastic dance scene out of nowhere. Caleb was me watching that scene in the movie just like '.....What??'

Both intelligent and engaging, Ex Machina is a sci-fi thriller at the forefront of a new movement for science fiction. The details are withheld as to the year or even the location of Nathan's research facility, but it feels so soon in the near future that it could be as close as tomorrow. The highest praise must be reserved for Alicia Vikander. Her portrayal of the female AI named Ava is so complete that you almost believe it is real. Without her flawless robotic tics and gestures, the suspension of belief would end and the film turn into a charade. This performance is truly a masterclass, and should serve as a paragon for future forays into the genre. Both Oscar Isaac and Domhnall Gleeson are also gripping in their respective turns as Nathan and Caleb. The film revolves around the dynamic between their two characters as well as that between Caleb and Ava. With this tight cast, each role must be played extremely carefully, and each of the three do exactly that. Isaac plays Nathan's grand deceit to a tee, while Gleeson is at his best when speaking few words and letting his expressions do the talking.Lastly, the screenplay. What a gripping story full of twists to the very end. The viewer is almost thrust into the shoes of Caleb, rooting for his well-being, but also kept in the dark on what exactly is going on. The ending may turn off a few, but it is a slickly intelligent way to end a very smart film.

The 2015 science fiction film Ex Machina was written and directed by Alex Garland, who as a screenwriter is making his first directorial debut with this movie. Written directly for the screen, it stars Domhnall Gleeson as Caleb Smith, a computer programer, Oscar Isaac as Nathan Bateman, the owner of the company that Caleb works for and Allcia Vikander as Ava, Nathan?s Ai creation. The film tells the story of Caleb who as a computer programmer working for Bluebook, a popular Internet search engine has been invited by Nathan, his boss, to administer the Turing test (which is a test of a machine's ability to display intelligent behavior equal to, or the same as that of a human and to persuade the tester it truly is human) to an android with artificial intelligence at Nathan?s secluded facility in the mountains on an island retreat. The only other person at this retreat is a young Japanese housemaid named Kyoko (Sonoya Mizuno), who cannot speak and is also an android. Caleb however believes that this is an unfair test as he already knows that Ava is a robot, but his real job is to decide whether or not Ava has a consciousness that Caleb can relate to. Nathan has researched personal information, hacked cell phones for people?s expressions and body language, so Ava would appear more realistic.Caleb, through the conversations he has with Ava, becomes more connected to her, while communicating with her through a transparent wall, since she is not allowed out of her apartment. She triggers blackouts to shut down the surveillance system so she can tell Caleb to not trust Nathan as he is a liar. Nathan informs Caleb that Ava will be reprogrammed in the future and in essence kill her current personality. Caleb discovers that Kyoko is also a robot and finds the previous creations which have been deprogrammed.Ava initiates another blackout where Caleb tells her that he will get Nathan drunk and help her escape. It is during the following day that he finds out that the real motive for inviting him was to see if Ava could persuade him enough to help her escape. Caleb has already reprogrammed the doors to open, but Nathan knocks him unconscious and damages Ava, while Kyoko stabs Nathan, who dies. Ava, slightly destroyed by Nathan takes some pieces from the other android prototypes and appears as a real human woman. She puts on a dress, walks out of the retreat and leaves Caleb trapped inside. Picked up by a helicopter that was meant to take Caleb off the island retreat, Ava enters human society. Garland has written and directed a modern day science fiction film that does not rely on a lot of special effects, but ideas that lean toward defining what is humanity or the lack of it, the limits of consciousness, and robots rebel against those who have created them (typical familiar themes in the science fiction genre). I give the director credit for the use of his ideas and androids to explore society?s female and male roles. It was different; however, it fell off in the third act and attempted to ?wrap it up? and give a somewhat usual ending. The acting by the three main characters, particularly Issac, was well done, as was the visual effects and cinematography. The makeup and clothing were more than appropriate. The real questions that I took away from this film were: what does it mean to be human and where does gender live? In the brain? Appearance? And if it is in the brain, what is the difference between male and female consciousness and is there really a difference? Due to the fall off in the third act, I will give this film a slightly smaller rating. But I really enjoyed it. It made me think. I hope it does the same to those of you that have or will see it. GRADE: 4 of 5 Crowns

It's been far too long since I've seen a movie with such economic exposition! Within the first five minutes, Caleb wins a contest, helicopters out to a remote paradise, meets genius-inventor-gone-rogue Nathan, and becomes the human component in an AI Turing Test, and we're off on a twisted android/creator/savior hate-triangle that challenges our notions of God, patriarchy, and humanity.I loved Domhnall Gleeson and Alicia Vikander's simmering chemistry in "Anna Karenina," and they are even more quietly explosive here as an ordinary computer programmer who falls under the spell of the dangerously alluring robot, Ava. Ava uses her sexuality, but she is not the typical femme fatale with only the one trick. Nathan and Caleb debate her sexual anatomy versus her sexual agency, and her fierce fight for autonomy from her God/father makes for a white-knuckle creation allegory tinged with sexual politics. Vikander is grace personified, Gleeson does a good American accent, and excellent-in-everything Oscar Isaac plays the mad scientist with fast and loose insouciance.I do wish, however, that the script better defined the criteria for humanity. Not being well-versed in bio-robotics, I still think of androids as robots, but the movie's thesis hinges upon the supposition that they're not - that a robot programmed to have that high a level of human consciousness is essentially human. As such, I didn't quite understand why Caleb calls Nathan a monster for so blithely dismantling his beta versions. Also, the big reveal is played out for the audience's benefit with unrealistic suspense that is incongruous to what Caleb already knows.
Engaging, fascinating, and thoughtful, Ex Machina is a rare artificial intelligence film that has a brilliant story, good direction, and great performances from its actors.

Dr. Noonien Soong would turn in his grave for this outmoded and uninspired A.I. drama. While the premise depends too much on the irrational fear of robots taking over the world, it just feeds into the paranoia of giant tech corporations unleashing a monster that can't be contained. Pretty generic stuff right? Yes.There is an overload of symbolism and techno babble that makes me want to cry out loud... "We get it man!" It is understood that we've got to be skeptical about new technology but this 'Greek Gods banished their own creators' theme tied into technophobia is overdone now and so is Frankenstein's monster and so is the Luddite fallacy.The geeky beta test plot also wears off after some time. One starts to wonder that why wouldn't the creator just unveil the invention to public by now like Google Glass or Self Driving Cars. After all we've accepted them without much hoopla! This film fails to establish whether man should feel proud or worried about creating an artificial life form, all the while assuming that it would hold us in contempt and ultimately bring our demise. Ex Machina was as brilliant of a science fiction thriller as you will see this year, maybe ever. Written and directed by Alex Garland, this masterfully crafted sci-fi gem captures viewers' attention from the moment the opening credits roll.Set in a world far more advanced than contemporary society, Ex Machina tells the story of an unassuming programmer, Caleb (Domnhall Gleeson) who is invited to the home of his wildly intelligent and eccentric CEO, Nathan (Oscar Isaac). While at the home/research facility, Caleb is tasked with evaluating life-like intelligence which happens to be the beautiful AI, Ava (Alicia Vikander); Nathan's most advanced AI model.In true form to the genre, Ex Machina intrigues and thrills while unraveling in a way that keeps you guessing until the end credits roll. As Caleb gives Ava the Turing test, her humanistic qualities and advanced intelligence endear evaluator to subject in ways neither can expect (audience included). The CEO Nathan's intentions remain closely guarded to his vest as he oversees the two's budding relationship.First time director, Garland is remarkable in how he brings his Academy Award worthy script to life by flooding the dialogue with satirical jabs at technology and man's insatiable appetite for advancement. This film utilizes minimal scenes -- mainly Nathan's massive estate -- with this setting becoming more ominous as the story progresses in true thriller fashion.What Garland does best in this film is what will ear mark this film as a genre defining classing. While the audience sifts it's way through the story, most minds will be working out a plethora of scenarios as the evaluator, Caleb and his subject, Ava become increasingly intertwined as the plot continues to twist. This film is as unpredictable as they come while being sure to leave audiences polarized by Garland's conclusion.This movie is a solid "A" in my book. And any reviewer that grades this instant sci-fi classic otherwise, may have not been able to grasp it's intelligence in it's entirety. Not Garland's fault. This is as refined of a directorial debut as you will ever see. It isn't only the direction; the acting by all three main characters breath ample life into the characters and story. It's just a very well polished machine with few flaws if any.
I was mesmerized from the very first frame. So much craft put into every detail of this film, both in its story and execution.
Disappointing because the plot had plenty of potential.

Directorial debuts are events that can either stand out/take the industry by surprise or to be forgettable. Screenwriter Alex Garland (responsible of "Sunshine", 2012�s "Dredd" and the beloved "28 Days Later") managed to make a directorial debut that have been noticed by numerous lovers of the seventh art and received various complements. Is this film that good? Caleb Smith is an employee of a major Google like corporation called "BlueBook". One day the owner of the company requires his cervices so Caleb flights to his private island to meet this man, called Nathan Bateman, who shows him the biggest achievement of his career and an invention that will change the world: AI. Nowadays people associate the sci-fi genre with action films/generic summer blockbusters set in space, but in reality this genre is supposed to be a social commentary or to preset some philosophical ideas with the background being the future, like "Planet of the Apes", the original "Star Trek", "Metropolis", "2001 A Space Odyssey" and "A Clockwork Orange"; so Alex Garland�s directorial debut had potential to be one of the those films and the result is a remarkable half success. "Ex Machina" counts with beautiful locations/sets, a solid soundtrack, impressive performances with Oscar Isaac being the standout, various ideas are presented that provide a though provoking experience, great special effects, a marvelous suspense vibe in which the audience doesn't know who to trust for the majority of the film, a story that's a modernize version of Mary Shelly�s "Frankenstein" combined with "THX 1138", peculiar and interesting characters, dialog that stands out, and a Kubrick like atmosphere (slow pacing that completely works, not a lot of color and Steady Cam movements). With all that being say, this film has two colossal problems: Alex Garland�s directing is average, and the film ruins the mystery that it flawlessly made in the beginning by the time the third act begins (sort of what Garland did in "Sunshine"). It is predictable, clich� and frustrating because all the questions this film asked are ultimately for nothing within this narrative. "Ex Machina" is a film that presents numerous interesting ideas and offers a though provoking experience that's starts with such amazing potential but sadly in the end it loses most of that promise. It is a more than solid and though provoking sci-fi film but it's shattered with a predictable third act. A film that's undeniably worth watching if you are into the genre.

If there is one question that EX MACHINA begs its audience to ask, it is this: How far will we take technology before it outsmarts the human race?Garland, has made a film that shows us how scared we should be of our near future. EX MACHINA is a sci-fi thriller that turns artificial intelligence into a reality, foreshadowing our course of history, should technology keep advancing at its ever-accelerating pace. Alicia Vikander, who delivered a stellar performance, will fool you into forgetting she's just a beautiful and talented actress and not really a beautiful and talented A.I. experiment.

Ex Machina is an engaging thrill ride that requires a lot of thought. Cleverly written and beautifully shown through the visually stunning scenery and effects. Domhnall Gleeson, Alicia Vikander, and Oscar Isaac all give their best efforts in this science fiction film that is successful in each of its own unique ways. 5/5

Ideas, philosophies, morality, and visually striking piece of cinema - Ex Machina started as a promising Sci Fi flick and went on to become almost poetic. Squabbling over AI, singularity and transcendence isn't new, but the way Ex Machina handles machine consciousness is outstanding. The arguments made by both the male characters are thought provoking and leave their impressions. The AI who was the centre of the story aka AVA came to 'life' thanks to a brilliant portrayal by Alicia Vikander. Her expressions, movements and dialogue delivery always reminded me how lifelike an AI can be while still retaining some form of machine like systematic articulation. But then, one wonders going through the movie, just like Gleeson's character Caleb, if there still existed a boundary between the two - man and machine. Perhaps the best Sci-Fi flick of 2015, a must watch!

Caleb is a nerdy 26-year-old coder for a search engine company. He wins a contest that entitles him to spend a week at the remote compound of the company's founder, a brilliant recluse named Nathan whose hobbies include drinking to excess and working out. Nathan has invented an incredibly lifelike robot named Ava and he asks Caleb to interact with her to assess if he thinks her A.I. is sophisticated enough for her to pass as human. As robots go, Ava is very hot. Actually, despite having a bald metallic head and a see-through torso, she's much hotter than most human women. This isn't lost on Caleb, who in the process of evaluating Ava, seems to be falling in love with her. "Ex Machina" is an extremely cool-looking movie. From the pristine mountain setting amidst glaciers and waterfalls, to the high-tech house, to Ava herself, the look and feel of the movie is half the enjoyment. The other half is the sheer unpredictability of it all. There's very little In the way of action in this movie. Ava talks to Caleb. Caleb talks to Nathan. Caleb observes Ava. Nathan observes Caleb. There's a feeling that something sinister is going on, but neither Caleb nor the audience is quite sure what it is. Do we trust the buff, bearded genius or the sexy, bald robot?If you like your science fiction on the cerebral side, this is a good film for you. But if you're more a fan of action and special effects - Sandra Bullock spinning wildly through space anyone? - then you're likely to be bored out of your skull as, I assume, was the guy on my right who spent the entire movie texting.I'm unconvinced that everything in this movie makes complete sense plot-wise, but it almost didn't matter how it ultimately resolved itself, because as some wise man once said, sometimes the journey is better than the destination, especially when the journey has A.I. robots.
Like Ava, Ex Machina goes beyond our beliefs on what a sci-fi flick should be. It puts the fear of smart technology in you.

After winning a competition Domhnall Gleeson's Caleb is taken to the remote sanctuary of his boss Nathan, played by Oscar Isaac. There he discovers something truly remarkable, the first possible artificial intelligence in the form of a feminine robot played by Alicia Vikander.I have been a fan of many of Alex Garland's previous work which includes the adaptation of Never Let Me Go (2010) and Sunshine (2007). His directorial debut was something I really looked forward to ever since seeing the first trailer. In my opinion, this will join the aforementioned films as some of my favourite sci-fi movies. Ex Machina is intriguing from the very beginning, with Caleb arriving at the secluded mansion almost instantly. The house is a sight to behold, being constructed among nature so beautifully. The design of everything in the movie is sleek, but the real marvel is the A.I body. A beautiful, almost human body, with an excellent sound design that feels almost real. The body looks so elegant, but also eerie in its likeness to a normal body that has been perverted by technology. Ex Machina's storyline is constantly absorbing, not taking the ordinary route of making the A.I extremely powerful and impossible to understand, instead creating a character that feels like they could exist unsettlingly soon. The film takes an interesting route with the main plot revolving around how we would know when an A.I is in fact an A.I., with many questions left to ponder. Beyond the story the film is pretty enjoyable to watch, with many winks to the audience making jokes about itself. The acting in this film had to be really strong for three people to carry the movie and they all pull it off. Oscar Isaac is brilliant as a strange, brilliant inventor whose motives remain ambiguous. The real star of the movie is undoubtedly Alicia Vikander. Her every move seems just noticeably unnatural and robotic but still somehow almost human. Almost.The weakest part of the film would be the ending, with the film being perhaps just a little too long. The film does have an interesting ending that isn't the traditional twist you start to expect but they still could have cut the last few scenes. The multitude of environment shots dispersed through every cut also slow the film slightly. Ex Machina is a great film that I really enjoyed, and the more time spent thinking about the many aspects of the film, the more I like it. Although some may find the film slow at times, I think that it builds at a good pace that kept me captivated. With little comedic elements sprinkled throughout, I think most people could enjoy this movie, although those who choose to analyse deeper will be rewarded the most. This is one of the best movies of the year so far and something I highly recommend especially if you enjoy sci-fi or Alex Garland.

THIS RATING REQUIRES CLARIFICATION:Simply put: it's not a bad movie, and it's WELL ABOVE average... but the problem that stems is from the clear fact that unfortunately Alex Garland is really, really bad at endings. His setups and characters and overall plots are great... Sunshine and Beach being two of my favourite films. But their endings have always felt ... off. Case in point: EX MACHINA... not only do the characters suddenly do things that are not within the established rules of what we have been shown, but they go against their own very nature. Has Nathan seriously never ready ANY sci-fi ever and simply neglected some minor important rules... yet still is smart enough to cunningly test both his AI and human subjects (and invent AI of course)... is the security system out the middle of nowhere REALLY tied to just 1980's keycards? Is there no fail-safe at all when a certain character leaves these enormous, obviously well-controlled security measures in place??Ex Machine works very well when the three lead characters are in conversations between themselves... but in the 3rd act simply goes into "oh look something shocking" route and frankly annoyed me beyond belief. Here is a film that transcends SO MUCH of the recent action-only climaxes... and then promptly falls into "6-year old red" territory.

High-concept, near-future sci-fi that I thought I would like more than I did. Possibly this is due to the fact that I watched it on the tiny screen on an airplane. However, maybe it was because this genre is starting to feel too pat, too self-satisfied, too ready to use flashes of violence or sexuality to spice things up (or to attract the teenage male viewers). Ex Machina is being talked about as more "intelligent" than most of its ilk, probably because the plot hinges on the "Turing Test", the challenge a computer (or robot in this case) must beat in order to be determined to have artificial intelligence. True, you never quite know whether Oscar Isaac, as a computer genius "dude", is telling the truth (but he probably isn't) to the young employee he brings in to test his sexy robot -- and this creates some suspense. But something authentic seems lacking and, in the end, intelligence is scrapped for dimestore psychology and the usual conventions of the thriller. Others liked this better.

This is writer Alex Garland's first time in the director's chair. He is known for his novel The Beach - which became an unsuccessful film starring Leonardo DiCaprio - and exquisite sci-fi screenplays for Sunshine and 28 Days Later... - both indie hits for Oscar-winning director Danny Boyle. Ex Machina shows the promise of good things to come even if it's a little "been there, done that". Oscar Isaac (Drive; Inside Llewyn Davis) plays Nathan, a billionaire inventor who lives in a palatial, jungle compound pf stone, glass, and iron where he creates AI and gives it the bionic body of a hottie played by newcomer Alicia Vikander (soon to be seen in The Man From UNCLE with Superman Henry Cavill; and The Danish Girl with Eddie Redmayne). She and her fellow autoerotic fem-bots have obviously been doing more than learning how to interact with their creator on an existential level. You know what I mean? When Caleb arrives (played by Harry Potter's Domhnall Gleeson), he's asked to test Ava to see if she passes convincingly as a human. A cat and mouse game a la Blade Runner ensues, and Caleb soon realizes that all life - even artificial - deserves some decency. The eccentric genius Nathan and he have nothing in common in regard to the responsibility which comes with creating life. A quiet, tense film, Ex Machina is absorbing enough but I don't think the actors quite sell it in the end. Gleeson and Isaac are mismatched as nemeses, and Vikander is too much of a cypher to give the full cold-blooded ending the gravitas it needs.
Thought provoking, brilliant.

Veteran screenwriter and first time director Alex Garland aped a phrase from a Greek tragedy to title his film about a gifted programmer who wins the opportunity to spend a week testing the newest A.I. model from a reclusive and charismatic genius. Stretching the admittedly simple plot wafer thin, Garland fills the gaps with philosophical dialogue, tributes of Old Testament literature, a chilling electronica soundtrack, stunning cinematography and enough metaphors for 10 movies. Ex Machina is a modern day Blade Runner; a phenomenally shot science-fiction trek that forgoes all clich�s affiliated with the genre and serenades you with an ominous atmosphere, fantastic performances and a remarkably fresh take on the AI/human relationship debate. It's a thought-provoker that ends on an ambiguous notion instead of wrapping things up neatly, opening things up to an even greater debate which, depending on the nature of your film interest, either ruins the flow or is the cherry on top to the most virtuoso sci-drama of this century "

Subtle and suspenseful with enough food for thought.Something about Ex Machina completely engrossed me into it. The 108 minutes smoothly passed away despite the slow-burning nature of its screenplay. Writer and debut director Alex Garland explores numerous ideals related to humanity with a seemingly basic premise and setup. A.I. Robots in movies is nothing new but Garland's visions here are not something you would be able to see if you just scratch the surface.A young nerdy programmer Caleb (Domhall Gleeson) receives a mail that he has won some big coding contest. We see that his face is being unknowingly scanned by his webcam and phone cam. As the prize he gets to spend a week at his company's (Blue Book) CEO's place, which is a luxurious estate amidst beautiful mountains. CEO Nathan (Oscar Isaac) tells Caleb its not a home but more of a research facility. The facility is modern and sleek, the rooms have no window and you have instant claustrophobic feel about it. Nathan tells Caleb is here to perform Turing Test on his creation, Ava (Alicia Vikander) an incredibly advanced A.I. Robot who looks lifelike with skin on her face . Caleb is as stunned as we are watching Ava. She is able replicate human-like behavior with extreme precision and even can perform lie-detection based on micro-expression on our faces!! She is charming as well and we see Caleb & Ava growing fond of each as they interact every day as part of the test. Everything is monitored by Nathan through CCTV cameras. Things seem smooth until one day Ava tells Caleb not to trust Nathan when cameras are shut by power cut. From here on the story takes an unpredictable turn, there is no clue who is right and who is wrong or who is the protagonist and who is the antagonist.The film explores various concepts such the meaning of consciousness and self-awareness, it questions your ethical viewpoint and blurs effectively the line between the human mind and AI. Are AIs truly the next stage of human evolution? Is singularity possible? It explores in these regions in great depth at the same time leaves some things open for interpretation. Adding to it, the film is also a suspenseful psychological thriller where you think every character is not what he/she seems to. And there are only 3 main characters here, all in the claustrophobic setting of the estate. The scene where Caleb cuts his hand to check if himself is a robot was really intense and frightening. There is also one hilarious out-of-the-box dance sequence giving a brief break from the freakish atmosphere. The soundtrack mostly of piano is haunting and beautiful at the same time. The music sets up requisite atmosphere and tone perfectly. The camera work is simply beautiful, be it the external landscape or the sleek interior shots. The production design and special effects are also impressive considering the low-budget of the film. At the end, cannot forget the 3 actors who did a great job. Alicia Vikander I feel nails every expression as the AI Robot and captures your attention in every scene she is present. Domhall as the lonely nerd and Oscar as the alcoholic genius were great too. Debut director Alex Garland shows immense potential and I am very much looking forward towards his next work. Overall, Ex Machina I believe is treat for all the true science-fiction fans and also those who like slow-burning atmospheric thrillers. There is not much superficial robot action here as it is not sci-fi action film. Its a film driven by ideas not by action. Hope you keep that in mind. If you want a movie deeply rooted towards the ideals of AI, Ex Machina is not to be missed. It was intriguing, thoughtful, tense and beautiful in its own way. Absolutely loved it!RATING: [4/5]

So not perfect but nonetheless film-making encompassing such interesting ideas like this should continue to be encouraged.

Small cast, big ideas: that's usually a winning formula for me. And at its core, Ex Machina stretches to reach a very challenging subject: where we draw the line between smart programming and true cognizance. The very idea of artificial intelligence opens up all manner of intriguing moral disputes on its own, particularly when a mammoth global corporation is responsible, and many of those are touched, or maybe clubbed, as the plot slowly unfolds. It has a habit of oversimplifying at points, though, and frequently relaxes into a simple good vs. evil framework that I thought was too easy for the theme's inherent complexities. Intense and thought-provoking at its best, but it has a bad habit of hammering points that would be best treated with a little subtlety. I wanted to like it a lot more than I did.

I don't wanna write something about the script as there are no harsh or abrupt events and the whole movie is a discussion around the logics and feelings, joy and disappointment. The movie is very stylish and beautiful, brilliant nature, unique scenes, bright colors. Acting is good, for me it is not a movie, that demands brilliant acting skills. Of course, there are some aspects that could be done in different way, for example the end of the movie, which was quite predictable for me. Critically acclaimed and featuring both Domhnall Gleason and especially Oscar Isaac, Ex Machina sounded like a brilliant piece of science fiction. There are so many films available today which explore the concept of emotions within artificial intelligence that you can find one in every corner of your DVD rental store. But Ex Machina stands out because it spends a lot of time building a complicated narrative towards a brilliant conclusion. However, the central fault in doing this is the fact that this massively slows down the film. The story is a very slow moving one which progresses at a gentle rate, allowing viewers time to take in the many questions posed by the film and the possibilities of where the story goes. However, as a result it takes a long time to really take off. The progressing relationship between Caleb Smith and Ava is intriguing, but it takes a long time to progress while the film puts a lot of philosophical questions forth, leaving viewers puzzled. This is to compensate for the lack of action in the film which actually proves sensible at times because it allows the feature to be more of a narrative driven one about characters and concepts, but amid all the mind-boggling concepts thrown around in Ex Machina, the actual content of the film does not always see eye to eye. When I say that I mean that the film looks good and puzzles the brains of its audience, but it is easy to get bored somewhere along the way because it takes so long to get anywhere.The film takes a turnaround as it gets closer to the end because things become so much more intense, the mystery in the narrative hits a high point and then keeps the viewer guessing. This is where the film turns almost surreal with its ambiguity and the potential answers to the narratives and where the intelligent nature of the film hits a high point. This is where the slow experience of the film all becomes worth it, where the underlying themes of the text all become unravelled and the originality of the story really goes into effect. The slow burning atmosphere of the film hits a high point during these moments by progressively reaching a new extent of intense strength. Though I found myself inconsistently entertained by the first half of Ex Machina, the second half of the film is a lot more intelligent and gives an effective climax to what the rest of the film has been working towards as a science fiction thriller. This effectively ensures that the film succeeds as a substance-driven film, though the style is also of value.Even though Ex Machina is not an action packed film and all takes place within the one location with heavily moderated use of visual effects, the visual style of the film is excellent. The scenery of the film gives a nice look of isolation to the film while the production design does effectively convey a futuristic sense of technology, as do the top notch visual effects. But what is most impressive about all this is how it is all captured with beautiful cinematography. With an intensely atmospheric style reminiscent of the imagery created by Daniel Landin for Under the Skin, Ex Machina has cinematography which manages to make the most of the limited scenery and cleverly shows the large and empty nature of the claustrophobic setting. At the same time, they cleverly illuminate the characters. This works in capturing the appearance of Ava to emphasize both her convincing humanity and her cyborg nature at the same time, while it zeroes in on the progressively unravelling psychology of Caleb Smith and the blank mindset of the brilliant yet desensitised Nathan Bateman. The cinematography fills Ex Machina full of simple and yet captivating imagery with beautiful little details to it, and it is enhanced even further by the way that it plays with the lighting and colour scheme. And as such a concept-driven film, Ex Machina demands the talents of a great cast and finds them easilyDomhnall Gleeson gives one of his best performances to date in Ex Machina. He begins in an intense dramatic mindset from the word go, and he just keeps getting better from there because he progressively gets into the material and intensifies his psychology nicely. He conveys the most through the stare in his eyes and his stern line delivery, making his performance subtle in delivery yet intense in depth. The balance is brilliant, and so he creates a complicated character who leads the story very well. Domhnall Gleeson builds a new level of credibility for himself with his leading performance in Ex Machina.Oscar Isaac's performance is great because of how unpredictable he is. Though he seems rather laid-back on the surface, Oscar Isaac conveys a sense of bluntness to the character Nathan Batemen which reflects his desensitised approach to the concept of man vs. machine. And the entire time, there is a feeling underneath the skin of the character that is of true brilliance. Oscar Isaac is instinctively intelligent in the role and yet unhinged at times, being able to deviate between those two concepts with a naturally charismatic ease. He is an actor who just continues to impress me.But even with such excellent performances from these two actors, it is Alicia Vikander who makes the greatest impact with her performance. There is not a second where I did not believe she was a cyborg because she is so firmly rooted in the character that she delivers it all so easily. And yet at the same time, she really had me questioning the extent of emotions being experienced by the character. The level of depth that Alicia Vikander is able to find in Ava is brilliant because she is intense and unpredictable yet sympathetic at the same time, and her chemistry with both Domhnall Gleeson and the universe around her really cry out a sense of progressing intelligence. Her performance is built on subtle physical actions most of the time and yet she is able to do so much through this little details of movement and facial expressions that she really makes a powerful role out of Ava. Alicia Vikander works exceptionally well in Ex Machina which is truly a beautiful sight to behold, and because she is so firmly entrenched in the character she is too convincing to not believe throughout all the subject matter that the character faces.So Ex Machina is slow with a first half that proves semi-decent at best, but all the questions that it ends up asking are answered with an intense and intelligent climax at the end of the film while the exceptional skills of the cast prove to keep things entertaining until then.
Not the most original of plots, but fairly interesting anyways.
